DEPARTMENT OF FINANCE




 



33.01  DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.




   The Department of Finance shall be under the direction of a Director of
Finance, who shall be responsible to the City Manager. The Director of
Finance shall perform the following duties:










   (A)   Keep in proper books a full and accurate record of all moneys
received and disbursed on behalf of the city and of all moneys due to and
from the city upon contracts and orders upon which the city is obligated and
otherwise.










   (B)   Have custody of all moneys paid to the city, when received by
him, and to disburse all city moneys in accordance with the Charter and
ordinances, signing all warrants upon the city treasury in making the
disbursements.










   (C)   Render a monthly report to the City Manager and to Council
reflecting the  financial condition of the city, showing monthly balances of
all appropriations and quarterly receipts in all funds.










   (D)   Certify that funds are available according to law to pay
moneys provided by all contracts, agreements or other obligations for the
expenditure of city funds, and no contract, agreement or other obligation
shall be valid until so certified.










   (E)   Make payment of the interest and principal on the bonded debt
when due, and keep accurate records of the debt and of the payments thereon.










   (F)   Prepare the city payrolls.










   (G)   Administer all employee pension and benefit funds, receiving
the funds, acting as custodian thereof and making disbursements therefrom,
signing warrants and checks for the purposes, according to law.










   (H)   Enter into contracts with legal depositories for the deposit
of all funds of the city with depositories; rent safe deposit boxes or
otherwise provide for the safekeeping of securities and other documents for
payment of money to the city, and maintain custody of all documents
evidencing investments of the city and of pension and benefit funds of city
employees.










   (I)   Render invoices for water consumption and sanitary sewer rents
to purchasers, collect, and deposit moneys from consumers in payment for
water consumption and sanitary sewer rents.  Render such reports of
receipts, deposits, and balances as determined to be necessary for proper
accounting records.  The above invoices and records shall be based on
records provided by the Department of Service.  Submit quarterly report to
Service Director of total gallons of water registered for revenue.










   (J)   Prepare and submit reports as may be required by law.










   (K)   Assist the City Manager in the preparation of the annual
budget.










   (L)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.





('70 Code, § 135.01; amend. Ord. 2154, passed 8-28-79; amend. Ord. 2291,
passed 10-27-81)









33.02  CONTRACTS AND PURCHASE ORDERS.




   Every undertaking by the city involving the expenditure of city money
shall be in writing, in the form of a purchase order or of a contract as may
be appropriate, and no officer or employee of the city shall have authority
to enter into any oral agreement involving the expenditure of money.  The
City Manager shall sign all contracts on behalf of the city and he or those
designated by him shall sign all purchase orders. The Finance Director shall
attach to each contract a certificate signed by the Finance Director that the
estimated amount of money required to meet the obligation of the city by the
contract has been lawfully appropriated and in the city treasury or in the
process of collection to the credit of the fund involved, free from any prior
encumbrance.  In the case of a contract to continue beyond any current year
and to involve expenditures of money in future years, the Director of Finance
shall only certify as to the money estimated to be paid by the city
thereunder during the current year. 
('70 Code, § 135.02; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.03  PAYMENT OF FUNDS.




   The Finance Director shall require invoices to be submitted to him with
written certificate thereon by the head of the department and division of the
city concerned to the effect that the goods or services for which the invoice
is rendered have been delivered or performed in the manner, quantity and
quality specified, prior to the issuance of the city's warrant in payment
thereof, whereupon the city's warrant shall be promptly issued in payment. 
('70 Code, § 135.03; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.04  PAYROLLS.




   (A)   Department heads shall be responsible to see that time sheets
or time cards with their verification thereon are submitted to the Finance
Director at a time and in a form as prescribed by the Finance Director.










   (B)   Payrolls shall be submitted to the City Manager for approval,
when prepared by the Finance Director and, upon the City Manager's approval
thereof, the Director shall issue his warrants in payment thereof when due. 
It shall not be necessary for the Director to encumber in advance or to
certify as to the availability of funds appropriated for personal services,
except those obtained on a contractual basis, provided that upon issuance of
the warrants the Director shall immediately cause the appropriate funds to be
encumbered to the extent of the warrants issued. 
('70 Code, § 135.04; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.05  PAYMENTS ON CONSTRUCTION TYPE  CONTRACTS.




   Prior to the making of partial or final payments on construction type
contracts, the City Manager and the City Engineer shall certify that the
conditions of the contract for which the payment is to be made have been
complied with.  In the case of partial payments, the payments shall be made
on estimates of the amount and value of the work accomplished; the
certificates or estimates shall include only the amount and value of the work
accomplished and materials used since any preceding estimate; the
certificates or estimates shall further indicate that a greater portion of
the contract has been performed by the contracting party than that which is
represented by the requested partial payment, in addition to any preceding
partial payments.  Upon receiving the certificates, estimates or invoices,
properly certified, the Finance Director shall then issue warrants in
payment. 
('70 Code, § 135.05; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.06  BOND OF THE FINANCE DIRECTOR.




   The Finance Director shall furnish bond, as required by the Charter, in
the sum of $50,000, the premium for which shall be paid by the city.  The
bond shall be for the protection of the city and the public against loss due
to acts or omissions of the Finance Director.
('70 Code, § 135.06; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.07  TREASURY INVESTMENT AUTHORIZED.




   Whenever there are moneys in the treasury of the city which will not be
required to be used for a period of 6 months or more, the moneys may, in lieu
of being deposited in a bank or banks, be invested by the Director of Finance
in accordance with the provisions of R.C. §§ 731.56 through 731.59. 
Investments so purchased shall be sold in accordance with R.C. § 731.57.





('70 Code, § 135.07)









33.08  ALLOCATION OF EARNINGS AND LOSSES OF TREASURY INVESTMENT.




   (A)   Premiums and discounts on treasury investment purchases shall
be credited to or charged against and amortized over the period from purchase
to date of maturity of the security.  Gains and losses in the sale of
treasury investment securities shall be credited to or paid from interest.










   (B)   Net interest realized by the treasury investment account shall
be distributed quarterly as follows: interest on bonds and special assessment
funds shall be paid to the bond retirement fund; the interest on any fund
created by the terms of any trust, will or agreement, which by the terms of
the instrument must be credited to the fund, shall be paid to each of the
respective funds; the balance of the interest from any fund or security held
by the treasury investment account shall be paid to the general fund.










   (C)   For the purpose of distributing interest, each fund shall be
considered as having, during the period for which distribution is to be made,
an average daily balance in the treasury investment account equal to the
average of the balances each fund has in such account on the first day of
each month during the period for which distribution is to be made. 
('70 Code, § 135.08)









33.09  DIVISION OF INCOME TAX.




   The Division of Income Tax shall be under the direction of the Finance
Director.  The Division shall perform the following functions:










   (A)   See that all persons required by the income tax ordinance file
necessary returns, and that all income tax moneys due the city are collected
when due and deposited.










   (B)   Render reports of total receipts, deposits and balances to the
Finance Director as determined by him to be necessary for his records.










   (C)   Keep accurate records of all accounts and make sure that all
information concerning individual and business returns is kept in strictest
confidence.










   (D)   Analyze any returns which are questionable by obtaining
information needed to determine accuracy of such returns as provided for in
the income tax ordinance and resolution, or subsequent amendments thereto. 
Refer unresolved cases to the Income Tax Board of Review, along with
sufficient information for them to reach a decision.










   (E)   To administer the income tax ordinance and resolution and all
subsequent amendments thereto.










   (F)   To perform other duties pertaining to the Division of Income
Tax as the City Manager may direct. 
('70 Code, § 145.01; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)










DEPARTMENT OF SAFETY









33.10  COMPOSITION OF DEPARTMENT.




   The Department of Safety shall be under the direction of the Safety
Director.  It shall be composed of the Division of Police and Division of
Fire, and any other divisions as may hereafter be established. 
('70 Code, § 137.01)









33.11  DIVISION OF POLICE.




   The Division of Police shall perform the following duties in providing
police services to the city:










   (A)   Be responsible for the preservation of the public peace and
order, the prevention and detection of crime, the apprehension of offenders
of law and ordinances, the protection of persons and property and the
enforcement of the criminal laws of the United States and of this state and
the ordinances of the city.










   (B)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.





('70 Code, § 137.02; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.12  CHIEF OF POLICE.




   The Chief of Police shall be in charge of the operation of the Division
of Police and of the personnel thereof, and shall be responsible to the
Safety Director.  He shall perform the following duties:










   (A)   Formulate and recommend to the Safety Director for approval
policies, procedures, rules and regulations for the government and operation
of the Division of Police and its personnel.










   (B)   Be responsible for the performance by the Division of Police,
of the duties assigned to it by the Charter, by the law, by this
administrative code and by the Safety Director.










   (C)   Have control of the assignment of all police personnel.










   (D)   Provide for the training and instruction of all personnel in
the Division of Police.










   (E)   Act as liaison officer in the cooperation by the city with
other law enforcement agencies.










   (F)   Perform any other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Safety Director. 
('70 Code, § 137.03; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)










33.13  BOND OF CHIEF OF POLICE.




   The Chief of Police shall furnish bond in the amount of $10,000, the
premium for which shall be paid by the city.  The bond shall be for the
protection of the city and the public against loss due to the acts or
omissions of the Chief of Police. 
('70 Code, § 137.04; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.14  DIVISION OF FIRE.




   The Division of Fire shall perform the following duties in providing
fire and ambulance services to the city:










   (A)   Be responsible for the prevention and detection of fire, and
the protection of persons and property where fires or other disasters are
involved.










   (B)   Be responsible for providing ambulance services.










   (C)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe.





('70 Code, § 137.05; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.15  FIRE CHIEF.




   The Fire Chief shall be in charge of the operation of the Division of
Fire and of the personnel thereof, and shall be responsible to the Safety
Director.  He shall perform the following duties:










   (A)   Formulate  and recommend to the Safety Director for approval,
policies, procedures, rules and regulations for the government and operation
of the Division of Fire and its personnel.










   (B)   Be responsible for the performance by the Division of Fire of
the duties assigned to it by the Charter, by the law, by this title and by
the Safety Director.










   (C)   Have control of the assignment of all fire officers and
equipment.










   (D)   Provide for the training and instruction of all firemen and
officers.










   (E)   Act as liaison officer in the cooperation by the city with
other fire agencies.










   (F)   Perform the other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Safety Director. 
('70 Code, § 137.06; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.16  BOND OF FIRE CHIEF.




   The Fire Chief shall furnish bond in the amount of $10,000, the premium
for which shall be paid by the city.  The bond shall be for the protection
of the city and the public against loss due to the acts or omissions of the
Fire Chief. 
('70 Code, § 137.07; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.17  AUXILIARY POLICE.




   (A)   Organization.





      (1)   A volunteer department to be hereafter known as the West
Carrollton Auxiliary Police Department is hereby established and organized
pursuant to R.C. § 737.051.  The primary purpose of this department shall
be to assist the police department in their regular and special duties.





      (2)   All members shall serve on a volunteer basis and the
compensation for the service shall be $1 per year, payable annually.










   (B)   Membership.





      (1)   The membership shall be limited to 12 regular (active)
members and 6 standby (inactive) members.





      (2)   Applications for membership shall be forwarded to the
police chief who shall check the applicant and recommend approval or
disapproval to the City Manager.  The police chief will appoint and remove
members with the advice and consent of the City Manager.





      (3)   Auxiliary police do not have the right to appeal in case
of removal or discharge.





      (4)   Applicants shall complete the standard city employee
application form.





      (5)   Applicants must pass a physical given by the city doctor.





      (6)   All new members shall be required to complete the state
approved police course as soon as practical after acceptance. Attendance at
training courses sponsored by the police department is mandatory.





      (7)   Resignation of any member shall become effective upon
written notice to the police chief and return of the badges, patches,
uniforms and equipment that were issued to him.





      (8)   Any auxiliary policeman may request being placed on
temporary inactive status due to personal or business reasons. The request
must be in writing and must be approved by the police chief.










   (C)   Uniforms and equipment.





      (1)   Any uniforms or equipment purchased from the auxiliary
organization funds shall become the property of the police department.





      (2)   Uniforms and equipment will be prescribed, replaced,
furnished by and will remain the property of the city.





      (3)   Uniforms will be furnished to active members only.










   (D)   Auxiliary duty rules.





      (1)   Auxiliary members shall be governed by rules and
regulations of the police department.





      (2)   Any member on regular duty shall be under orders of the
regular police officer on duty.





      (3)   A member on cruiser duty will remain in the car unless
otherwise ordered by the regular officer, except as otherwise covered under
rules and regulations of the police department.





      (4)   A member will drive a cruiser only on orders of or by
permission of a regular officer, and the cruiser will be driven in the manner
prescribed by the state and city ordinances for emergency vehicles.  The
dispatcher will be informed when an auxiliary policeman is driving a cruiser.





      (5)   A member on regular duty will wear the complete uniform
in a neat and proper manner.  A member on emergency duty will wear his badge
and should wear the cap, if possible.





      (6)   An auxiliary detail on sports, parade or other special
duty will be under orders of the police chief or the regular officer on duty.










   (E)   Auxiliary police fund.





      (1)   An auxiliary police fund may be maintained by the
organization.





      (2)   The auxiliary police may accept donations to the
aforementioned fund for services performed, but may in no instance solicit
for funds for the organization.










   (F)   Auxiliary off-duty rules.





      (1)   A member shall not use his badge, wear the uniform or
engage in auxiliary work when not on regular, special or emergency duty.





      (2)   When reporting for any type of duty, the member shall
drive any personal or privately owned vehicle in the normal and lawful
manner, and not as an emergency vehicle.





      (3)   When reporting for any type of duty, the member shall
report to the regular officer or dispatcher and sign the time card, and his
presence for duty shall be noted.










   (G)   Auxiliary rules of disciplinary action.  Members shall be
governed by the same rules as regular police officers, except they do not
have the right to appeal, as specified in division (B) (3) of this section.










   (H)   Meetings.





      (1)   The regular meetings of the organization shall be set by
the Police Chief.





      (2)   Any active member who shall absent himself from 3
consecutive regular meetings without acceptable cause shall be discharged
from the organization.










   (I)   Officers.





      (1)   The officers of the auxiliary shall be the president and
secretary-treasurer.





      (2)   The president and secretary-treasurer shall be appointed
by the Police Chief.
('70 Code, § 137.08; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.18  LAW ENFORCEMENT TRUST FUND  ESTABLISHED.




   (A)   The Finance Director is hereby directed to establish a Law
Enforcement Trust Fund in the records of the city.










   (B)   All contraband proceeds shall be deposited in the Law
Enforcement Trust Fund established.










   (C)   Such contraband funds shall be used only for law enforcement
purposes as appropriated by the City Council.
(Ord. 2693, passed 1-10-89)









33.19  EMERGENCY AMBULANCE SERVICES.




   (A)   The following fees are hereby established to be charged for
emergency ambulance services provided by the city:










      (1)   For Residents and Non-Residents of the City of West
Carrollton, Ohio:




 


Basic Life Support Service (BLS)

 

$ 650.00




Advanced Life Support  (ALS-1)

 

$ 850.00




Advanced Life Support Service (ALS-2)

 

$ 1050.00




Mileage (per mile to the hospital)

 

$  15.00










      (2)   With respect to charges established for city residents,
the City of West Carrollton shall accept the assignment of third party
benefits paid on behalf of the patient as the usual and customary charge for
the service provided as payment in full for services rendered.  City
residents shall not be responsible for any out-of-pocket expenses as a result
of the taxpayer supported income tax. For purposes of this section, a West
Carrollton resident shall be any person whose principal place of residence is
located within the City of West Carrollton at the time the service is
rendered.





         (Ord. 3540.  Passed 12-10-13.)










   (B)   The following policies are hereby established by this Council
to govern the collection procedures to be used by the city in recovering said
charges:





      (1)   EMT/Paramedic personnel will make reasonable efforts to
obtain the address and insurance information of all recipients of emergency
ambulance services.





      (2)   All recipients of emergency ambulance services will be
sent an informational letter explaining the charges established herein and 
requesting additional insurance information as necessary.





      (3)   Claims will be filed with recipients' insurance carriers
for reimbursement of charges.





      (4)   Recipients will be furnished a statement showing
insurance payment collected.





      (5)   Under no circumstances will threats of litigation be
issued or suits be filed by the municipality in an effort to collect the
charges established herein, without prior approval of Council.





         (Ord. 3085, passed 2-24-98)










DEPARTMENT OF SERVICE









33.20  DIVISION OF STREETS.




   The Division of Streets shall be under the direction of the Service
Director.  The Division shall perform the following functions:










   (A)   Maintain, repair, construct, improve and extend the public
streets of the city.










   (B)   Maintain, repair, construct, improve and extend the storm
sewer systems of the city.










   (C)   Apply and maintain all traffic control signals, signs and
markings upon the streets and curbs of the city.










   (D)   Maintain maps and records of the streets, storm sewers,
buildings and premises which may be necessary to properly operate the
department.










   (E)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Service Director.
('70 Code, § 139.01; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.21  DIVISION OF REFUSE COLLECTION.




   The Division of Refuse Collection shall be under the direction of the
Service Director.  The Division shall perform the following functions:










   (A)   Collect, remove and dispose of garbage, brush, trimmings,
refuse and trash from residences and other places within the city in
accordance with Chapter 53, or subsequent amendments thereto.










   (B)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Service Director. 
(Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.22  DIVISION OF WATER.




   The Division of Water shall be under the direction of the Service
Director.  The Division shall perform the following functions:










   (A)   Operate, maintain and repair the water works system of the
city, including the buildings used by the same, the wells, distribution
lines, meters, tanks and fire hydrants; and perform the distribution of water
through the system as pumped by the city from its wells and as purchased from
other agencies, to the residences, hydrants and other places where water is
used within the city.










   (B)   Maintain accurate records of water pumped for annual state
reports.










   (C)   Operate and maintain the water system in accordance with state
requirements and maintain necessary records of operation.










   (D)   Maintain proper maps of the water distribution system of the
city.










   (E)   Perform other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to the
Service Director. 
('70 Code, § 139.02; amend. Ord. 2154, passed 8-28-79; amend. Ord. 2291,
passed 10-27-81)









33.23  DIVISION OF SANITARY SEWER.




   The Division of Sanitary Sewer shall be under the direction of the
Service Director.  The Division shall perform the following duties:










   (A)   Operate, maintain and repair the sanitary sewer system of the
city, including the buildings used by the same and the water pollution
control facilities.










   (B)   Operate and maintain the water pollution control facilities in
accordance with state requirements and maintain necessary records of
operation.










   (C)   Maintain proper maps of the sanitary sewer system of the city.










   (D)   Perform other duties pertaining to the sanitary sewer system
as the City Manager may prescribe to the Service Director.





('70 Code, § 139.03; amend. Ord. 2154, passed 8-28-79; amend. Ord. 2291,
passed 10-27-81)









33.24  DIVISION OF BUILDING AND ZONING  INSPECTION.




   The Division of Building and Zoning Inspection shall be under the
direction of the Service Director.  The Building and Zoning Division shall
perform the following duties:










   (A)   Make inspections of buildings and premises, and issue permits
for the construction, alteration and demolition of buildings pursuant to the
building code of the city and/or state, individually and with the assistance
of other agencies with whom the city may now or hereafter contract to perform
inspection services.










   (B)   Receive applications for permits, review proposed plans for
buildings and determine compliance of prepared plans with uses permitted
under the zoning ordinance of the city.  Issue, upon approval by the Service
Director, permits under the zoning ordinance upon applications complying with
the ordinance.  Make inspections of premises and buildings for the purpose
of enforcing compliance with the zoning ordinance and make reports of
violations thereof to the Service Director.










   (C)   Maintain accurate records of new sewer taps and render such
records to the Finance Department for billing.










   (D)   Issue zoning certificates as required by zoning ordinances,
upon approval of the Service Director.










   (E)   Perform such other duties pertaining to the Division of
Building and Zoning Inspection as the City Manager may prescribe to the
Service Director. 
('70 Code, § 139.04; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.25  BOND OF BUILDING AND ZONING INSPECTOR.




   The Building and Zoning Inspector shall furnish bond in accordance with
the Charter in the amount of $5,000, the premium for which shall be paid by
the city.  The bond shall be for the protection of the city and the public
against loss due to the acts or omissions of the Building and Zoning
Inspector. 
('70 Code, § 139.05; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.26  TRANSFER OF PERSONNEL.




   The Service Director may temporarily transfer employees from one
division under his jurisdiction to another division under his jurisdiction to
expedite the work of a particular division or to meet increased duties of a
seasonal, emergency or periodic nature which may occur. 
('70 Code, § 139.06; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.27  BOND OF SERVICE DIRECTOR.




   The Service Director shall furnish bond in accordance with the Charter
in the amount of $10,000, the premium for which shall be paid by the city. 
The bond shall be for the protection of the city and the public against loss
due to the acts or omissions of the Service Director. 
('70 Code, § 139.07; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)










DEPARTMENT OF LAW









33.30  DUTIES OF DIRECTOR.




   The Department of Law shall be under the direction of the Law Director
and responsible to Council.  He shall perform the following duties:










   (A)   Attend all regular meetings of Council and special meetings of
Council committees, boards and commissions, when requested.










   (B)   Advise and render opinions to Council, to the City Manager, to
boards and commissions and to the administrative officers and departments on
all matters of law involving the city and Council members, officers and
departments in the performance of their official duties.










   (C)   Draft or approve as to form, all ordinances, contracts,
resolutions and other documents of a legal nature to be made and entered into
by the city.










   (D)   Represent the city before all courts sitting within the state
in actions at law in which the city is a party.










   (E)   Assist in the preparation of documents and transcripts for the
issuance of bonds and notes of the city.










   (F)   Prosecute in the Mayor's court and other courts of
jurisdiction when necessary, all cases based on affidavits filed therein by
the police division and by other city officials, alleging violations of city
ordinances and of state laws, and prosecute cases based upon affidavits filed
in court by private parties as appear to the Law Director to be meritorious.










   (G)   The Law Director may, with the approval of Council, retain the
services of an assistant and/or trial counsel to perform the duties herein
required to be performed by the Law Director.










   (H)   The Law Director shall perform such other duties consistent
with his office as may be required by the Charter, by ordinance or resolution
of the Council, or by the laws of the state unless otherwise provided by
ordinance of Council. 
('70 Code, § 141.01; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.31  BOND COUNSEL.




   Whenever Council proposes to issue bonds or notes to finance public
improvements, or for any other purpose authorized by the laws of the state,
the Law Director may, upon Council approval, engage the services of any firm
of recognized bond attorneys to assist the Law Director in causing the bonds
and notes to be issued and to render or furnish approving opinions thereon to
purchasers of bonds and notes. 
('70 Code, § 141.02; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.32  BOND OF THE LAW DIRECTOR.




   The Law Director shall furnish bond as required by the Charter, in the
amount of $5,000, the premium for which shall be paid by the city.  The bond
shall be for the protection of the city and the public against loss due to
acts or omissions of the Law Director. 
('70 Code, § 141.03; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)










DEPARTMENT OF PARKS AND RECREATION









33.40  POWERS AND DUTIES.




   The Department of Parks and Recreation shall be under the direction of
the Parks and Recreation Director who shall be responsible to the City
Manager.  The Parks and Recreation Director shall perform the following
duties:










   (A)   Develop and implement a variety of recreation programs and
activities for leisure time enjoyment.










   (B)   Maintain and repair city buildings and grounds.










   (C)   Operate and maintain the swimming pool.










   (D)   Develop plans and implement improvements in the city parks
system.










   (E)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Parks and Recreation Director. 
(Ord. 1777, passed 4-10-73; amend. Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.41  BOND OF PARKS AND RECREATION DIRECTOR.




   The Parks and Recreation Director shall furnish bond, as required by
the Charter, in the amount of $10,000, the premium for which shall be paid by
the city.  The bond shall be for the protection of the city and the public
against loss due to acts or omissions of the Parks and Recreation Director. 
(Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)

CITY BEAUTIFUL COMMISSION









33.45  ESTABLISHMENT OF COMMISSION.




   A city beautiful commission is established for the city.
(Ord. 1707, passed 11-23-71)









33.46  OBJECTIVES OF COMMISSION.




   The objectives of this commission shall be as follows:










   (A)   To make specific recommendations to Council for improvements
in the appearance of streets, parks, buildings and other property owned or
controlled by the city.










   (B)   To sponsor, promote, coordinate and otherwise encourage both
individual and collective beautification efforts by business, industry and
the general citizenry.










   (C)   To generate city-wide interest, pride and action related to
beautification through contests, awards and similar programs.





(Ord. 1707, passed 11-23-71)









33.47  NUMBER OF MEMBERS.




   The City Beautiful Commission shall consist of fifteen (15) members who
shall be residents of the City, or persons who work within the City, and
shall be appointed by the Council in such a manner as to provide broad
geographical representation.  Members of the Commission shall serve without
compensation.





(Ord.  3191.  Passed 10-23-01.)









33.48  LENGTH OF TERM.




   All members of the commission shall serve for a term of 2 years except
that 7 members of the commission first appointed shall serve for one year in
order to provide for overlapping of terms.  The terms of those members first
appointed shall be effective January 1, 1972, and the appointment of new
members to the commission shall be made effective on January 1st of each year
thereafter. 





(Ord. 1707, passed 11-23-71)









33.49  YEARLY BUDGET PROPOSAL.




   The city beautiful commission shall annually submit a budget proposal
to the City Manager for funds to carry out its activities for the ensuing
year.  This budget proposal shall be subject to the same review,
modification and approval procedures as other departmental budgets.  All
purchases and expenditures of moneys by the commission shall be according to
rules and regulations adopted by the City Manager and in accordance with
purchasing requirements established for all city departments. 





(Ord. 1707, passed 11-23-71)









33.50  RECORDS TO BE KEPT.




   The city beautiful commission shall adopt its own rules and elect its
own officers annually.  It shall keep current and complete records of its
meetings and activities, and shall present an annual report to the Council on
its yearly activities prior to January 31 of each year.





(Ord. 1707, passed 11-23-71)










BOARD OF TRUSTEES OF THE DAYTON-MIAMI VALLEY





REGIONAL ARTS AND CULTURAL DISTRICT









33.55  DEFINITIONS.




   For the purpose of this subchapter the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.










   ARTISTIC OR CULTURAL FACILITY.  Includes, but is not limited to, a
performing arts center, a concert hall, a museum, a living arts center, and
other property, improvements, or facilities used in connection therewith.










   ARTS OR CULTURAL HERITAGE.  Includes, but is not limited to,
literature, theater, music, dance, ballet, painting, sculpture, photography,
motion pictures, architecture, archaeology, history, natural history, and the
natural sciences.










   ARTS OR CULTURAL ORGANIZATION.  Any nonprofit corporation, arts or
cultural council, association, institution, or other organization, no part of
the net earnings of which inures or may lawfully inure to the benefit of any
private shareholder, member, or individual, that provides programs or
activities in areas directly concerned with the arts or cultural heritage.










   BOARD.  The board of trustees of the district.










   DISTRICT.  The Dayton-Miami Valley regional arts and cultural district
created in § 33.56, and includes the territory within the geographical
limits of each member, as the limits may change from time to time.










   DIVISION LINE.  U.S. Route 35 except that the division shall follow
the boundaries of Mad River Township, Village of Riverside, and Village of
New Lebanon which are north of U.S. Route 35.










   MEMBER.  Each political subdivision joining in the creation of the
district, as enumerated in § 33.56.










   NORTHERN MEMBERS.  Those members (excluding the County of Montgomery
and the City of Dayton), all or a majority of the territory which lies north
of the division line.










   SOUTHERN MEMBERS.  Those members (excluding the County of Montgomery,
the City of Dayton, and the City of Kettering), all or a majority of the
territory of which lies south of the division line.





(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.56  CREATION; PURPOSE.




   The County of Montgomery, Ohio, the City of Dayton, Ohio, the City of
Oakwood, Ohio, the City of Kettering, Ohio, the City of Centerville, Ohio,
the City of Trotwood, Ohio, the City of Vandalia, Ohio, and the City of West
Carrollton, Ohio hereby join in creating a regional arts and cultural
district pursuant to the provisions of R.C. Ch. 3381.  The official name of
the district shall be Dayton-Miami Valley regional arts and cultural
district.  The principal office of the district shall be located in Dayton,
Ohio, or in another place in Montgomery County, Ohio as may be selected by
the board.  The purposes of the district shall be to make grants to support
the operating or capital expenses of arts or cultural organizations located
within the district, and to acquire, construct, equip, furnish, repair,
remodel, renovate, enlarge, improve, or administer artistic or cultural
facilities.





(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.57  BOARD OF TRUSTEES.




   (A)   The board shall be composed of 11 trustees who shall serve
without compensation, provided that with the approval of the board, trustees
may be reimbursed for actual expenses incurred in the performance of their
duties.










   (B)   The city commission of the City of Dayton shall appoint three
trustees; the board of county commissioners of the County of Montgomery shall
appoint three trustees; the city council of Kettering shall appoint one
trustee; and one trustee shall be appointed by the southern members and one
trustee shall be appointed by the northern members, all in accordance with
division (C) below.










   (C)   The appointment of trustees by the southern members and the
northern members shall be accomplished by rotating the appointment power as
provided in this paragraph.  With respect to the southern members, initially
the legislative authority of the City of Centerville shall appoint one
trustee.  Thereafter, the appointment power shall rotate among the
legislative authorities of the southern members in alphabetical order.  With
respect to the northern members, initially the legislative authority of the
City of Trotwood shall appoint one trustee.  Thereafter, the appointment
power shall rotate among the legislative authorities of the northern members
in alphabetical order.  Notwithstanding the foregoing, the legislative
authority of any southern member or northern member may, by written notice to
the board given at least 90 days prior to the commencement of a trustee term
for which the member has the appointment power, waive the right of the member
to appoint the trustee for such term, whereupon the appointment power shall
vest in the member next having the appointment power as herein provided.










   (D)   In addition to the trustees appointed as stated above, there
shall be two trustees appointed in the following manner, which trustees shall
be persons who devote a major portion of their time to practicing,
performing, or teaching any of the arts or who are professional
administrators in any field of the arts or cultural heritage.  The city
commission of the City of Dayton and the board of county commissioners of the
County of Montgomery shall each propose one of such trustees for
consideration by the other four members which have appointed or have the
power to appoint trustees at such time under division (B) above, and each
such proposed trustee shall be appointed by the proposer only if the proposed
trustee is approved, prior to the appointment, by at least two of the other
members.










   (E)   The initially appointed trustees shall serve staggered terms
of one, two, and three years as follows:  of the trustees appointed by the
city commission of the City of Dayton, one shall serve a term of one year and
two shall serve terms of two years; of the trustees appointed by the board of
county commissioners of the County of Montgomery, one shall serve a term of
one year and two shall serve terms of two years; and the trustees appointed
by Kettering, the southern members and the northern members shall each serve
terms of three years.  The trustees initially appointed in accordance with
division (D) above shall serve a term of one year.  Thereafter, each trustee
shall serve a term of three years, except that any person appointed to fill a
vacancy shall be appointed only to the unexpired term.  Any appointed
trustee is eligible for reappointment.  The initial trustees shall be
appointed within 60 days after the creation of the district by all of the
members.  The term of each trustee of the board shall be deemed to run from
the date of his appointment. The legislative authority of each member may at
any time remove any trustee appointed by the legislative authority.










   (F)   All trustees of the board shall be persons who are qualified
electors in the district's territory and who have broad knowledge and
experience in the arts and cultural heritage.  Each legislative authority
with appointing power shall consider for appointment as trustees of the
board, but need not appoint, such persons as are nominated by area art
councils, as defined in R.C. § 757.03, located within the district, provided
that all such persons shall meet the qualifications specified in the first
sentence of this division (F).










   (G)   If any trustee resigns, expires, becomes disqualified, or is
removed from office, the legislative authority of the member which appointed
the trustee shall promptly appoint a person meeting the requirements of this
section to fill the vacancy.










   (H)   Upon the expiration of his term, a trustee shall remain in
office until a successor trustee is selected by the appropriate legislative
authority.










   (I)   A majority of the board shall constitute a quorum, the
affirmative vote of which is necessary for any action taken by the
district.  No vacancy in the board shall impair the rights of a quorum to
exercise all rights and perform all the duties of the district.










   (J)   Each trustee of the board, before entering upon his official
duties, shall take and subscribe to an oath or affirmation that he will
honestly, faithfully, and impartially perform the duties of his office.










   (K)   After each trustee of the board has taken the oath required by
this section the board shall meet and organize by electing one of its
trustees as president and another as vice-president, who shall hold their
respective offices until the next annual meeting of the board.  At each
annual meeting thereafter the board shall elect from its membership a
president and a vice-president who shall serve for a term of one year.










   (L)   The board shall appoint and fix the compensation of an
executive director, who shall be the fiscal officer and shall not be a
trustee of the board and who shall serve at the pleasure of the board.





(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.58  POWERS OF THE BOARD.




   All the power and authority granted to the district shall be vested in
and exercised by the board, which shall manage and conduct the affairs of the
district.  The board shall, within the limitations of R.C. Ch. 3381, provide
by rules the procedure for its actions, the manner of selection of its
executive director, and other employees, their titles, terms of office,
compensation, duties, number, and qualifications, and any other lawful
subject necessary or desirable to the operation and administration of the
district and the exercise of the powers granted to it. 
(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.59  POWERS OF THE DISTRICT.




   Upon the creation of the district and upon the qualifying of the board
and the election of a president and vice-president, the district shall
exercise in its own name all the rights, powers, and duties vested in and
confirmed upon it by R.C. Ch. 3381. 





(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.60  EXPENSES.




   (A)   On or before November 1 of each year, the district shall adopt
and transmit to each member a budget for the following calendar year.  The
budget shall determine the estimated operating expenses of the district to be
borne by the members (local expenses) during the calendar year.  Revenues
received by the district from any tax levied pursuant to R.C. § 3381.16
shall be applied to payment of local expenses before apportionment of local
expenses among members.  Until any tax is levied, local expenses in any
calendar year to be borne by the members shall not exceed $50,000.










   (B)   For any calendar year, local expenses shall be borne in the
proportions set forth herein by the members as have appointed or have the
power to appoint, pursuant to § 33.57 (B), trustees who will serve during
the calendar year.  Each of the members shall pay to the district local
expenses up to a maximum of $.02 per capita of the population of the member,
provided that for purposes of this sentence the population of Montgomery
County shall be deemed to be the same as the population of the City of
Dayton.  Any additional amount of local expenses shall be borne and paid
equally by the City of Dayton and the County of Montgomery if, and only to
the extent, provided in a resolution of the board of trustees adopted with
the affirmative vote of the six trustees appointed by the City of Dayton and
the County of Montgomery pursuant to § 33.57 (B).  All payments under this
paragraph shall be made quarterly on or before January 1, April 1, July 1,
and October 1 of each year.  For the purposes of this paragraph, a member
shall not be deemed to have the power to appoint a trustee if it has waived
the power pursuant to § 33.57 (D).










   (C)   Each member of the district may determine to provide its share
of local expenses from any funds authorized by law to be used for these
purposes.










   (D)   For the calendar year 1980, each member shall pay to the
district an amount of money agreed upon between the district and the
members.  The payments shall be made in equal installments on January 2, and
July 1, 1980.










   (E)   Notwithstanding anything herein to the contrary, no member
shall be obligated to bear any local expenses for any calendar year after
calendar year 1982. 
(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80)









33.61  DISSOLUTION.




   The district may be terminated and dissolved at any time by the
adoption of a resolution of termination and dissolution by either the
legislative authority of any member having a population of at least 55,000,
or the board and by the legislative authority of each member. The resolution
of termination and dissolution shall fix a date on which the district shall
be terminated and shall become effective upon the filing of a copy of each
resolution or ordinance adopting the resolution with the clerk of the
legislative authority of each member. In addition, the district shall
automatically terminate on the tenth anniversary of its creation unless by
that date a tax levy shall have been authorized by the qualified electors
pursuant to R.C. § 3381.16 (A) or 3381.16 (B).  Before any termination
date, the district shall proceed to wind up its affairs, fulfill or discharge
its contracts, collect its assets, sell its assets for cash at public or
private sale, discharge or pay its liabilities, make distributions to arts or
cultural organizations to the extent practicable, and do all other acts
appropriate to liquidate its business.  On the termination date, the
district, after paying or adequately providing for the payment of its
liabilities, shall distribute the remaining assets of the district (if any)
to the members in such a manner as may be agreed upon by the members.  After
the termination date, the district, its trustees, officers, and members may
continue to function for the purpose of winding up the affairs of the
district in the same manner as if the termination had not taken place.  In
so doing, the trustees shall not be deemed to be trustees for the assets of
the district and title to the assets shall remain in the district until
transferred by it. Until the winding up of the affairs of the district is
completed, this resolution and the bylaws of the district shall continue in
full force and effect.





(Res. 20-80, passed 8-12-80; Am. Res. 12-85, passed 10-8-85)










DEPARTMENT OF PLANNING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT









33.70  POWERS AND DUTIES.




   The Department of Planning and Community Development shall be under the
direction of the Director of Planning and Community Development who shall be
responsible to the City Manager.  The Director of Planning and Community
Development shall perform the following duties:

city including associated documents such as the zoning code and zoning map,
housing data, existing land use data, transportation plan and land use plan.










   (B)   Develop and maintain an up-to-date subdivision ordinance and
enforce the development standards set forth therein.










   (C)   Develop and implement various programs to foster economic
development.










   (D)   Develop and implement various community development programs
to improve the quality of life in the city including such programs as
downtown revitalization, housing rehabilitation, and the community
development block grant program.










   (E)   Develop and maintain an up-to-date sign code.










   (F)   Perform such other duties as the City Manager may prescribe to
the Director of Planning and Community Development. 
(Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)









33.71  BOND OF PLANNING AND COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT DIRECTOR.




   The Director of Planning and Community Development shall furnish bond,
as required by the Charter, in the amount of $10,000, the premium for which
shall be paid by the city.  The bond shall be for the protection of the city
and the public against loss due to acts or omissions of the Director of
Planning and Community Development.
(Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)

(Ord. 2291, passed 10-27-81)










BOARD OF WATER AND SEWER CHARGE ADJUSTMENT









33.90  ESTABLISHMENT.




   For provisions regarding the Board of Water and Sewer Charge
Adjustment, see § 50.30.










ATTENDANCE POLICY FOR BOARDS AND COMMISSIONS









33.100  ESTABLISHMENT, EFFECT OF POLICY.




   (A)   The following attendance policy is hereby adopted and made
applicable to any board or commission of the city which has not heretofore
adopted an attendance policy.  This policy shall in no way inhibit a board
or commission which has been granted the power or authority to adopt its own
rules and regulations from adopting its own attendance policy, so long as the
policy adopted is in substantial compliance with the policy stated herein.










   (B)   Boards and commissions which have previously adopted rules and
regulations shall submit a copy of their rules and regulations and any
amendments thereto to the City Manager in order to have those rules and
regulations recognized for the purposes of this subchapter.










   (C)   The City Manager shall provide a copy of this subchapter to
all present members of boards and commissions and to all members appointed
subsequent to its adoption.





(Res. 3-83, passed 1-11-83)









33.101  NOTICE OF MEETINGS.




   (A)   Each board or commission which holds regular meetings shall
publish a list of its regular meeting dates for the current calendar year and
shall provide the list to each of its members no later than January 10 of
each calendar year.  Failure to publish the list does not excuse attendance
at any regular meeting.










   (B)   In the case of those boards and commissions which do not meet
on a regular basis, all members shall be notified of a meeting by regular
mail postmarked five days prior to each meeting, or by phone 24 hours prior
to the meeting; or in the manner otherwise prescribed by the charter,
ordinances, or resolutions of the city or any previously adopted rules by
that board or commission.










   (C)   Any board or commission may hold a special meeting subject
only to the notice requirements specified above.





(Res. 3-83, passed 1-11-83)









33.102  UNEXCUSED ABSENCES.




   (A)   Attendance is required at all regular and properly noted
special meetings of boards and commissions.  Any member who accumulates
three unexcused absences during any calendar year shall be considered to have
tendered his/her resignation from that board or commission to the City
Council, which resignation shall be subject to City Council's acceptance. 
It shall be the responsibility of the secretary or chairperson of the board
or commission to provide written notice to the City Council when a member has
accumulated three unexcused absences within a calendar year.  The
notification may be affected by sending the notice to the City Manager.










   (B)   An UNEXCUSED ABSENCE is defined as any absence from a regular
or properly noticed special meeting for which the member has not notified the
chairperson or secretary of the board or commission or City Manager's office
in advance of the meeting of his/her inability to attend the meeting.  The
unexcused absence shall be noted in the minutes of the meeting along with the
names of those present and the names of those members who are excused.










   (C)   Any member of a board or commission who is absent from a
special meeting that has not been properly noticed as specified above shall
not be considered to have accumulated an unexcused absence for the purpose of
this subchapter.





(Res. 3-83, passed 1-11-83)










MUNICIPAL RECREATION BOARD









33.110  OBJECTIVES.




   The objectives of the Municipal Recreation Board shall be as follows:










   (A)   To promote a comprehensive recreation program including
various recreational areas and facilities for the citizens of the city;










   (B)   To make recommendations to Council on matters concerning
parks, recreation and leisure activities; and










   (C)   To act as a voice for the Parks and Recreation Department in
the community and a voice for the community in the Parks and Recreation
Department.





(Ord. 34-90, passed 12-11-90)









33.111  MEETINGS; QUORUM.




   (A)   Meetings shall be held on the third Tuesday of each month. 
Special meetings may be called by the Chairperson of the Recreation Board or
the Parks and Recreation Director.










   (B)   A quorum shall consist of at least three members, in addition
to the presence of the Parks and Recreation Director.  If three or more
members are present at a called meeting, they may take action on any subject
which rightly may come before this board.





(Ord. 34-90, passed 12-11-90)









33.112  OFFICERS.




   The officers of the Board shall be a chairperson, who shall conduct the
meetings of the Board, a vice-chairperson to serve in the absence of the
chairperson, and a secretary to keep accurate minutes of all meetings.  The
officers are to be elected by the Board for one-year terms at the regular
meeting in January.





(Ord. 34-90, passed 12-11-90)









33.113  CAPACITY OF BOARD.




   The Recreation Board serves in an advisory capacity.  Its advice is to
be reflected in minutes of its meetings or in other written presentations
which it may choose to submit.  The Board may recommend action to City
Council or the Parks and Recreation Director but may not assume any
legislative or administrative authority in the operation of the Parks and
Recreation Department.





(Ord. 34-90, passed 12-11-90)










BUSINESS ADVISORY COUNCIL









33.120  ESTABLISHMENT.




   A Business Advisory Council is established for the city.





(Res. 39-94, passed 10-25-94)









33.121  OBJECTIVES.




   The objectives of this Advisory Council shall be as follows:










   (A)   To review and make specific recommendations to City Council
concerning programs, policies and capital improvements which have an impact
on businesses in the city.










   (B)   To advance, encourage and promote the economic development of
the City of West Carrollton.










   (C)   To sponsor, promote, coordinate and encourage cooperation
between businesses in the city and local government to ensure competitiveness.










   (D)   To guide development of an aggressive economic development
marketing program for the city.










   (E)   To guide the development of a long-term strategic economic
development plan for the city.










   (F)   To generate city-wide interest, pride and action related to
economic development.





(Res. 39-94, passed 10-25-94)









33.122  MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.




   The Business Advisory Council shall consist of seven members who
conduct business in the city and shall be appointed by the Council in a
manner to provide broad representation of the types and sizes of businesses
located in the city.  Members of the Advisory Council shall serve without
compensation.





(Res. 39-94, passed 10-25-94)









33.123  TERMS.




   All members of the Advisory Council shall serve for a term of two
years, except that three members of the Advisory Council first appointed
shall serve for one year in order to provide for overlapping of terms.  The
appointment of new members to the Advisory Council shall be made effective on
January 1 of each year.





(Res. 39-94, passed 10-25-94)









33.124  RULES; OFFICERS.




   The Advisory Council shall adopt its own rules and elect its officers
annually.





(Res. 39-94, passed 10-25-94)










TECHNOLOGY ADVISORY GROUP









33.130  ESTABLISHMENT.




   The West Carrollton Technology Advisory Group is hereby established for
the city.





(Res. 22-97, passed 5-27-97)









33.131  OBJECTIVES.




   The objectives of the Technology Advisory Group shall be as follows:










   (A)   To guide and advise City Council and city staff concerning
programs, policies, and technological improvements which have or may have an
impact in the city.










   (B)   To increase citizen/community involvement in the application
of technology.










   (C)   To increase cooperative efforts with other area/regional
resources.





(Res. 22-97, passed 5-27-97)









33.132  MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.




   The Technology Advisory Group shall consist of nine members appointed
by the Council in a manner to provide a broad range of technical expertise.
Members of the advisory group shall serve without compensation.





(Res. 22-97, passed 5-27-97)









33.133  TERMS.




   All members of the advisory group shall serve for a term of four years,
except that four members of the advisory group first appointed shall serve
for two years in order to provide for overlapping terms. The appointment of
new members to the advisory group shall be made effective on January 1st.





(Res. 22-97, passed 5-27-97)









33.134  RULES; OFFICERS.




   The advisory group shall adopt its own rules and elect its officers
annually.





(Res. 22-97, passed 5-27-97)










INDEPENDENCE DAY FESTIVAL COMMITTEE









33.135  ESTABLISHMENT.




   The West Carrollton Independence Day Festival Committee is hereby
established to organize, promote, and implement this annual event.





(Res. 14-2006.  Passed 5-9-06.)









33.136  OBJECTIVES.




   The objectives of the Independence Day Festival Committee shall be as
follows:










   (A)   To work closely with community volunteers from throughout the
community to organize and implement this annual event.










   (B)   To generate Citywide interest, pride and involvement related
to the Independence Day Festival. 
(Res. 14-2006.  Passed 5-9-06.)









33.137  MEMBERSHIP; COMPENSATION.




   The Independence Day Festival Committee shall consist of nine members
appointed by the City Council.  Members of the Independence Day Festival
Committee shall serve without compensation.





(Res. 14-2006.  Passed 5-9-06.)









33.138  TERMS.




   All members of the Independence Day Festival Committee shall serve for
a term of three years, except for those first appointed, three members will
be to a one-year term, three members to a two-year term, and three members to
a three-year term; this is to provide for overlapping terms.  The
appointment of new members to the Independence Day Festival Committee shall
be made effective on January 1.  The Independence Day Festival Committee is
encouraged to form subcommittees and to invite board participation by
volunteers to further the success of this annual event. 
(Res. 14-2006.  Passed 5-9-06.)

PERSONNEL PROVISIONS; APPEALS BOARD




 



34.01  TITLE AND PURPOSE.




   (A)   This chapter shall be known as the Personnel Chapter and it
shall give effect to and augment the provisions of the City Charter
pertaining to personnel.  It is the policy of the city as a charter,
home-rule-municipality established under the constitution and laws of the
state, that this chapter and such rules as may be adopted in accordance with
the provisions herein shall supercede all civil service laws passed by the
state.  This shall be true even when this chapter and such rules are silent
on a particular topic which is included in the state civil service laws.










   (B)   Except as may otherwise be provided in this chapter, this
chapter shall only apply to personnel in the nonexempt positions of the
city.  Nonexempt positions are those which have not been exempted from the
civil service of the municipality or the competitive examination
requirements.  In accordance with the provisions of § 10.02 of the City
Charter, the following  positions are exempt from the civil service of the
municipality and the open competitive examination requirements:





      (1)   Members of Council;





      (2)   The Clerk of Council;





      (3)   The City Manager;





      (4)   The Directors of Departments;





      (5)   The Secretary to the City Manager;





      (6)   The Assistant to the City Manager;





      (7)   Members of Boards and Commissions appointed by the
Council; advisory committees appointed by the City Manager;





      (8)   Those positions requiring peculiar and exceptional
qualifications of a scientific, managerial, professional or educational
character;





      (9)   Unskilled laborers;





      (10)   Seasonal, provisional, temporary, or part-time
employees.










   (C)   In addition to the positions specified in division (B) above,
other positions may be exempted from the civil service or the competitive
examination requirements on the determination of the City Manager and the
approval by the Personnel Appeals Board.





('70 Code, § 153.01; amend. Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81)









34.02  PERMANENT STATUS.




   When this chapter becomes effective, all persons then holding positions
not included among those exempted by the city Charter shall have a permanent
status if:










   (A)   They were employed in positions on the date of passage of this
chapter (May 14, 1968) and have served their full probationary period.










   (B)   They shall serve a probationary period of one year or any
other period as may be prescribed by this chapter for the position held. 
('70 Code, § 153.02)









34.03  RECRUITMENT AND SELECTION.




   (A)   Original appointments and promotions to vacancies to the civil
service of the municipality shall be made solely on the basis of merit and
fitness demonstrated insofar as practicable by open competitive examinations
or other evidence of competence, except where open competitive examinations
for particular vacancies may be dispensed with as provided by the City
Charter and this chapter.










   (B)   Each open competitive examination shall be publicly announced
by the Personnel Director in such media as he may deem expedient.  The
announcement shall specify the title of the position classification for which
the examination is to be held; the time, place, and manner of making
application; the closing date for applications; the time and place for the
examination; the minimum qualifications for the position as established by
the Personnel Director and approved by the City Manager; and any other
information deemed pertinent by the Personnel Director.










   (C)   Application shall be made on the form prescribed by the
Personnel Director, and he shall conduct such investigation as he may deem
necessary to verify the truth of the statements made therein and to determine
the qualifications of the applicant.  He may reject any application which,
on its face, indicates that the applicant does not possess the minimum
qualifications established for the position classification and may also
reject any application which is received after the closing date established
for the examination.  In addition to the above, the Personnel Director may
refuse to examine an applicant or, after an examination, disqualify an
applicant from further consideration if the applicant makes a false statement
of any material fact, practices or attempts to practice any deliberate
deception or fraud in the selection process, or for such other reasons as may
be provided in the rules promulgated by the Personnel Director and approved
by the City Manager.










   (D)   All examinations shall be of such a type that will fairly
assess the relative abilities and aptitudes of the candidates to efficiently
and effectively perform the duties of the position classification for which
the examination is given.  The examinations may be written, oral, physical,
psychological, a demonstration of skill, an evaluation of training and
experiences, or any combination thereof. The Personnel Director shall
determine the nature of the examinations and the weight to be given to each
part.  He shall see that the examinations are graded, taking care to
preserve the anonymity of the candidates in the written portion until grading
is completed.
('70 Code, § 153.03; amend. Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81)










34.04  ELIGIBLE LISTS.




   (A)   From the results of each entry-level and promotional
examination, the Personnel Director shall prepare and certify an eligible
list for the positions for which the examination was conducted.  All
candidates receiving a passing score on the examination are to be ranked on
the eligible list in the order of their total scores.  In the event two or
more candidates receive the same total score on the examination, they shall
be placed in the same position on the eligible list and the tie shall be
noted.










   (B)   Reemployment.





      (1)   In the event it becomes necessary to lay off city
employees for any reason, the names of the persons laid off shall be placed
on a reemployment eligible list for the classification involved.  The names
on the list shall be ranked in order of classification seniority and each
name shall remain on the list for a maximum period of one year (except as
provided in division (2) below) unless such eligibility is extended by the
Personnel Director.





      (2)   Each name on a reemployment eligible list for the
classification of police officer, crime prevention officer, or dispatcher
shall remain on such list for a maximum period of 15 months unless the
eligibility is extended by the Personnel Director.










   (C)   All other eligible lists shall be valid for a minimum period
of one year from the original date of certification unless exhausted prior to
that time.  The validity of such lists may be extended for an additional
period, up to one year, by order of the Personnel Director.





('70 Code, § 153.04; Am. Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81; Am. Ord. 2463, passed
9-11-84)









34.045 REMOVAL FROM ELIGIBLE LISTS.




   (A)   If, after an eligible list has been established, it is 
determined that any candidate whose name appears on the eligible list has
obtained his place thereon by deception or fraud either in the application or
in the selection process, or that the candidate does not possess the minimum
qualifications established for the position, or that the candidate is subject
to disqualification under the provisions of § 34.03 (C), the name of the
candidate may be removed from the eligible list by order of the Personnel
Director. The Personnel Director may also remove the name of any candidate
who indicates that he is no longer interested in the position, who declines
to be interviewed for the position, or who refuses to accept appointment
after being certified.  Furthermore, the Personnel Director may remove the
name of any candidate whom, after a reasonable effort, he has been unable to
contact by mail or phone to determine the candidate's interest in a position.










   (B)   The Personnel Director may also remove the name of a person
from the eligible list if that person has been certified three times to the
same department head for the same or similar positions and has not been
appointed. 
(Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81)









34.05  PROMOTIONAL EXAMINATIONS.




   (A)   The Personnel Director, subject to the approval of the City
Manager, shall designate which classes of positions in the civil service are
entry-level positions and which are promotional positions.  Such designation
shall be based upon an analysis of the relative job requirements as well as
an examination of the logical career paths within the organization.










   (B)   A promotional examination shall be restricted to present
employees unless the City Council, on the recommendation of the City Manager,
adopts a resolution opening the examination to candidates outside of the
municipal service.  The promotional examination shall be competitive except
where the Personnel Director determines that there are three or less
qualified persons who are interested in the position, in which case the
examination may be noncompetitive.










   (C)   Eligibility for promotional examinations shall be determined
by the Personnel Director, subject to the approval of the City Manager, after
consideration of qualifications and length of service. For the Police
Division, eligibility requirements shall include a minimum of 12 months of
service in the next lower rank unless otherwise recommended by the Personnel
Director and approved by the City Manager.










   (D)   Where appropriate, promotional examinations shall give
consideration to the candidate's record of prior performance and seniority,
as may be provided in the rules promulgated by the Personnel Director and
approved by the City Manager.










   (E)   All candidates receiving a passing score on the examination
are to be ranked on the promotional eligible list in the order of their total
scores. 
('70 Code, § 153.05; amend. Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81)









34.06  CERTIFICATIONS AND APPOINTMENTS.




   (A)   Whenever a vacancy is to be filled in the civil service of the
city, the appropriate department head shall request the Personnel Director to
certify the names of the persons standing highest on the applicable eligible
list.  If no list exists for the particular position classification, the
Personnel Director shall schedule an examination at his earliest possible
convenience to establish an eligible list.










   (B)   If the vacancy exists in an entry-level position, the
Personnel Director shall certify the names of the top five candidates
including ties, remaining on the original appointment eligible list. If more
than one position is to be filled, the Personnel Director may certify a list
of names that is equal to the number of vacancies plus four, which list shall
also include ties.  If one or more provisional, probationary or permanent
full-time city employee receives a passing score on the examination, the name
or names of those employees shall also be certified.  When an eligible list
is reduced to less than 5 names, or when the list has expired, the Personnel
Director may conduct an examination to prepare a new list.










   (C)   If the vacancy exists in a position to be filled through
promotion, the Personnel Director shall certify the names of the top three
candidates, including ties, remaining on the promotional eligible list.  If
more than one position is to filled, the Personnel Director may certify a
list of names that is equal to the number of vacancies plus 2, which list
shall also include ties.










   (D)   If the vacancy exists in a position for which there is a
current reemployment eligible list, the Personnel Director shall certify the
name of the candidate in the highest position remaining on that list.  The
reemployment list shall expire or be exhausted before names are certified
from any other appointment list pertaining to that position classification.










   (E)   Whenever a certified eligible indicates his unwillingness to
accept appointment or has otherwise had his name removed from the eligible
list, leaving fewer candidates from which the department head may choose than
can normally be certified under divisions (A) through (D) of this section,
the Personnel Director shall then certify to the department head the name in
the next position on the eligible list.










   (F)   After receiving the names of those eligible for appointment to
a vacancy, the department head shall make his selection and shall notify the
Personnel Director of the person recommended for appointment.  Although the
responsibility of making the recommendation shall lie primarily with the
department head, any such recommendation must be approved by the City
Manager, as the appointing authority under the City Charter, before becoming
official.  The Personnel Director shall see that the person appointed is
placed on the payroll and shall restore to the eligibility list the names of
the other persons who were certified but not appointed.





('70 Code, § 153.06; amend. Ord. 2193, passed 2-26-80; amend. Ord. 2297,
passed 12-22-81)









34.07  TEMPORARY APPOINTMENTS.




   Whenever an emergency exists which requires that a vacancy be filled on
a temporary basis in order to maintain public services, the appropriate
department head may recommend to the City Manager the appointment of a person
qualified to perform the duties of the position.  On approval of the City
Manager, the appointment shall become official.  However, no temporary
appointment shall be for a period longer than 60 days unless otherwise
approved by the City Manager. 
('70 Code, § 153.07; amend. Ord. 2297, passed 12-22-81)









34.08  PROVISIONAL APPOINTMENTS.




   (A)   Whenever a vacancy occurs in the civil service of the city and
there is no current eligible list from which a certification can be made, the
Personnel Director shall so inform the appropriate department head.  If, in
the judgment of the department head, it is not expedient to await the
establishment of a list, he shall request the Personnel Director to submit to
him the application of one or more persons who possess the minimum
qualifications established for the position to be filled.  On review of the
