50.01  USE OF CITY WATER AND SEWER SERVICES.




   City water and sewer services shall be furnished to the inhabitants of
the city in a manner determined by the ordinances of the city, and by written
regulations established by the service director and approved by the city
manager.  All persons using city water or sewer or permitting city water or
sewer to be used on premises owned by them shall thereby evidence their
acceptance of an agreement to be bound by the rules, conditions and charges
established within such ordinances and regulations. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 9-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.02  WATER RATES WITHIN THE CITY.




   (A)    Effective at the beginning of the first quarter water billing
period of 2007, this section shall read as follows:





      (1)    The quarterly rates for metered water furnished and
supplied by the City within its corporate limits shall be as set forth in
Section 37.03 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances
of the City of West Carrollton.





      (2)    Water services furnished to premises not under
individual water meters shall be charged as set forth in Section 37.03 of
Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of
West Carrollton.





         (Ord. 3300.  Passed 6-14-05; Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









50.03  SEWER RATES WITHIN THE CITY.




   (A)    Effective at the beginning of the third quarter sewer billing
period of 2008, the quarterly rates for sewer provided by the City within its
corporate limits shall be as set forth in Section 37.04 of Chapter 37,
General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of West
Carrollton.





      (1)    Water usage not tributary to the sanitary sewer may be
separately metered at owner's expense to avoid billing for sewer.





      (2)    Commercial or industrial sewer users not under the City
or Montgomery County meter control shall have sanitary sewage flow estimated
at the ratio of 35 gallons per day per employee. The number of employees
shall be updated periodically by the City.  Nothing herein stated shall
constitute approval to discharge industrial or commercial wastes into the
municipal sewer system.





      (3)    Multi-family, commercial and industrial units not under
City meter control may have sanitary sewage flow estimated which will be
based on similar multi-family, commercial or industrial units under City
meter control whenever the City determines it would be impossible or
impracticable to actually read such meter.  (Ord. 3382.  Passed 4-8-08;
amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









50.04  SERVICE CHARGES OUTSIDE THE CITY.




   Charges for water and sewer services rendered outside the city
corporate limits shall be 20% over and above the standard charge for similar
service within the city, except that where different charges are authorized
by City Council and agreed upon by the consumer, the charges set forth in the
agreement shall apply.





(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.05  MEASUREMENT OF WATER AND SEWER USAGE.




   On or about the fifteenth of December, March, June, and September, but
prior to the end of these months, the city shall read all meters and compute
the usage of each service customer for the  calendar quarters ending with
those months.  This measurement of usage shall constitute the basis for
computation of quarterly billings based on graduated





rates.
(Ord. 1986, passed 10-26-76)









50.06  DETERMINATION OF BILLING PERIODS.




   Customers shall be billed for water and sewer charges at regular
quarterly intervals.  However, extended or shortened billing periods may be
adopted by the Service Director on a temporary basis with the approval of the
City Manager when necessitated by a shortage of labor, breakdown of machinery
or temporary other circumstances under which quarterly billing would be
impractical.  When modified billing periods are necessary, minimum charges,
where applicable, shall be determined on a pro rata basis.  However, no
billing period shall be for less than 30 days.  If, for purposes of
efficiency, regular quarterly billing on other than a calendar quarter basis
is determined to be desirable, a revised quarterly meter reading and billing
schedule may be established by the City Manager. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.07  ADDITIONAL FEES INCLUDED IN WATER OR SEWER BILLS.




   The following special services shall be charged to a customer's water
or sewer bill with the fees indicated:










   (A)   Posting Fee.  In all cases in which the account is posted on
the shut-off list for any violation of these regulations or failure to pay
charges, the owner or occupant of such premises shall pay a fee as set forth
in Section 37.05 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified
Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.










   (B)   Fee for Testing Meter Accuracy.  The Water Division will test
any of its meters and will guarantee their accuracy against overcharge within
2%.  Proper refund shall be made for any overcharges resulting from an
inaccurate meter.  In order to protect the Water Division from unreasonable
demands for this service, a charge as set forth in Section 5 of Chapter 37,
General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of West
Carrollton, shall be made if the test shows the meter to be registering
properly within 2%, plus or minus.










   (C)   Emergency Water Shut Off Fee.  Emergency water shut off fee
requested after hours by the customer, or plumber, which results in overtime
payments to water department employees shall be billed per occurrence at the
rate set forth in Section 37.05 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the
Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.





(Ord. 3353.  Passed 8-14-07; amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









50.08  PAYMENT OF WATER AND SEWER BILLS; SHUT-OFF ORDER.




   On a regular quarterly basis as provided for herein, a statement of the
amount due for water consumed, sewer usage and all fees, charges and/or
penalties shall be sent to the owner or to the address where water or sewer
services are delivered.  If the bill is not paid on or before the fifteenth
day after mailing of such notice, a 10% penalty shall be posted to the
account.  If the account is not paid within 28 days after mailing such
notice, a 48 hour notice of water shut-off shall be mailed to the affected
address and to the owner if that address is not his place of residence.  If
more than one user is to be affected by such shut-off, notices shall be
mailed to all of the persons.  If the bill is not paid upon the expiration
of the 48 hour period, the account number will be posted on a shut-off list
and a special shut-off fee will be assessed to the account at that time, in
accordance with § 50.07 of this chapter.  The water shall be shut off as
soon as practical after the 48 hour period and shall not be turned on again
until all water and sewer bills, penalties and charges are paid. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99










50.09  SHUT-OFF ORDER; NO LIABILITY.




   When one or more parties are supplied with water or sewer  from the
same service pipe and one or more of the parties so supplied fails to pay the
bills due or fails to comply with the rules of the water and sewer
departments, or a defect develops in any one of the systems connected, the
water shall be shut off from the service pipes without liability in damage to
any of the parties served.
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.10  RESPONSIBILITY FOR PAYMENT OF WATER AND SEWER CHARGES; REGULATIONS
FOR COLLECTION OF DELINQUENT ACCOUNTS.




   (A)   The payment of all water and sewer charges, penalties and
fees, shall be the responsibility of the property owner. Delinquent water and
sewer bills shall be collected according to the rules and regulations adopted
by the Finance Director and approved by City Council and set forth in
division (B) below.










   (B)   The following rules and regulations are hereby adopted and
shall be used for the collection of all delinquent water and sewer bills
owing to the city.





      (1)   Delinquency owing at change of ownership of property.
Where an outstanding amount appears on an account that either has had, or
will have water services shut off, and where the city is aware of the
delinquency at the time the services are transferred to the new owner, the
water clerk shall:





         (a)   Inform the new property owner of the amount due on
the account.





         (b)   Maintain a service shut-off on the property until
the outstanding amount is paid in full.





      (2)   Delinquency owing on final bill; nonrental property.





         (a)   Where an outstanding amount appears on an account
as a result of a user's failure to remit payment on their final reading, and
where this delinquency is apparent after ownership of the property has been
transferred, the water clerk shall:





            1.   Send a balance due notice to the previous
owner stating that payment is due within 15 days.





            2.   Send a second notice to the previous owner
stating that if the amount due is not paid in full, the amount will be
forwarded to the city's legal counsel for collection through the courts, or
the amount will be turned over to a credit bureau for collection.





            3.   Depending on the amount involved, file for
judgment in the small claims court, or place amount for collection with the
credit bureau.





            4.   Write-off amounts not collectible after all
collection avenues have been exhausted.





         (b)   Where a property owner sells a property, leaving a
final bill due, and moves to another location within the city, the water
clerk shall:





            1.   Send a shut-off notice to the new location
stating that if the amount due is not paid within ten days, service to their
current residence will be shut off.





            2.   Shut off service until amount due is paid.





      (3)   Delinquency owing on final bill; rental property. The
property owner of rental property shall be ultimately responsible for the
payment of all water and sewer charges for such property and such
delinquencies shall be collected as follows:





         (a)   Where an outstanding amount appears on an account
as a result of a tenant moving out of a property and leaving a final bill
unpaid, the water clerk shall:





            1.   Send a shut-off notice to the property owner
stating that if the bill is not paid within ten days, service to the property
will be shut off.





            2.   Shut off service until amount due is paid.





         (b)   Where an outstanding amount appears on rental
property that does not use the city's water system or where the owner of the
property is not known, collection efforts shall follow the procedures set
forth in division (B)(2)(a) of this section.





            (Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed
10-9-73; amend. Ord. 2675, passed 10-11-88)









50.11  SHUT-OFF REQUESTED; AUTHORITY.




   Either a property owner or tenant may request a termination of water
service. In the event of conflicting requests from property owner and tenant
regarding termination, the decision of the property owner shall prevail. 
The property owner shall hold the city harmless from damages resulting from
any order to the water department regarding either termination or
reinstatement of water services.





(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.12  UNMETERED FIRE LINE SERVICES AND HYDRANTS; CHARGES.




   (A)   Unmetered fire line services installed on private property
shall be subject to the charges set forth in Section 37.06 of Chapter 37,
General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of West
Carrollton.










   (B)   These services must be protected by backflow devices approved
by the service director and by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency. 
These services are for fire protection only and the use of water from them
for other purposes is prohibited.  Flow detectors approved by the service
department must be installed in these lines.










   (C)   A charge, as set forth in Section 37.06 of Chapter 37, General
Fee Schedule, of the City of West Carrollton, shall be applied to each
unmetered fire hydrant located on private property which is connected to the
city water supply. 





(Ord. 3350.  Passed 8-14-07; amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









50.13  ESTIMATED BILLS; CORRECTIONS.




   If a meter has failed to register the amount of water consumed or if
the meter has not been read, the bill shall be estimated. Estimated bills
will be corrected if the owner or consumer makes a request for correction
within 10 days after issuance of the bill and presents evidence satisfactory
to the water department that the correction is justified.





(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.14  SALE OF RESIDENCES OR BUILDINGS;  REPORT BY SELLER.




   Any person, firm or corporation selling any residence or other building
within the city shall, immediately upon the sale, notify the water department
clerk, in writing, of the facts and shall furnish the name and address of the
purchaser and the address of the property.
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.15  RESPONSIBILITY FOR METERS.




   The property owner shall be responsible for protecting water meters
from physical abuse, freezing, vibration, or other adverse conditions, and
shall assume the cost of repair of meters damaged under such conditions. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.16  LEAKS; NO REBATE.




   No reduction in charges for water or sewer will be made due to leaks in
customer water lines, tanks, pipes, or other fixtures or appurtenances,
unless so ordered by the Board of Water and Sewer Charge Adjustment. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73; Am. Ord. 2354,
passed 12-14-82)









50.17  FALSE INFORMATION.




   No person, firm, or corporation shall furnish any false information
concerning the use of water or sewer services or regarding the occupancy or
ownership  of premises in making application for the services, or in
responding to inquires by the water or sewer department regarding the current
status of the premises. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.18  AUTHORIZED USE OF SERVICES.




   No person, firm, or corporation shall connect to, or otherwise use the
water or sewer services of the city without first obtaining permission
therefor from the service director or his authorized agent.





(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.19  UNAUTHORIZED USE OF WATER; SPECIAL CHARGE.




   In addition to the criminal penalties provided herein, a special charge
shall be made for water taken illegally.  The charge shall be determined by
obtaining 3 quotations from private water haulers of the cost of delivery of
the amount of water illegally taken and the city's charge shall be the
average of the 3 quotations. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.20  AUTHORIZATION OF EMPLOYEES TO ENTER PREMISES.




   All employees of the city, designated for the purpose, are authorized
to enter, at reasonable hours and with the knowledge of the owner or
occupant, into any house, building or plant supplied with city water or sewer
for the purpose of inspection or repair, or for any other reasonable purpose
necessary to the operation of the city water or sewer systems. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.21  METER INSTALLATION OR REPAIR; NONRESPONSIBILITY FOR DETERIORATED OR 
INFERIOR PLUMBING.




   The city shall have the right to repair or replace meters, if
necessary, and shall not be responsible for damage to deteriorated or
inferior plumbing in making the repairs or replacement.
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.22  RIGHT OF CITY TO DISCONTINUE SERVICE FOR REPAIRS, MAINTENANCE OR
CONSTRUCTION.




   The city shall have the right to shut off water service temporarily
when necessitated by repairs, maintenance or construction, and shall not be
responsible for accidents or damage which may result from such
discontinuances.  Persons owning or operating equipment or businesses
dependent on the city water supply should make adequate provision for storage
of water to be used in case of a temporary discontinuance of city water
service. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.23  RIGHT OF CITY TO LIMIT USE OF WATER.




   In case of a serious fire or water shortage, or when for any reason it
is necessary, in the judgment of the city manager, to conserve the water
supply by limiting the use thereof, the limitations shall be obeyed by all
users of water affected by the limitations and the city shall not be
responsible for any damages resulting from the limiting of use.





(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.24  WATER SERVICES NOT TO BE RESOLD.




   Under no conditions shall water and water services as provided by the
city be resold by any consumer or furnished to any other living unit,
business, individual or property, except as herein provided.
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.25  ACCESSIBILITY OF HYDRANTS, METERS AND STOP BOXES.




   Hydrants, meters and stop boxes must be kept accessible and visible by
the owner and occupant. It shall be the duty of the property owner to assure
that no vegetation, structure, or other obstacle shall hinder the
accessibility of these fixtures. The property owner shall maintain all such
fixtures in accordance with regulations adopted by the city manager. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.26  FAILURE TO REPAIR LEAKS, ETC.; SHUT-OFF.




   Failure to repair leaks, remove obstructions preventing access to
meters or curb box, or to make payment of charges for work performed by the
city for these purposes, when notified to do so, will be sufficient cause for
termination of water service until the problem has been corrected by the
owner. 
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)  Penalty, see
§ 50.99









50.27  INSTALLATION AND MAINTENANCE OF CUSTOMER OWNED WATER METERS.




   Only those water meters approved by the city service department may be
used and the city shall have the right to check the meters for accuracy at
any time and require that any necessary repairs to the meters be  made at
the property owner's expense.  The city shall also have the right to inspect
connecting plumbing to assure that the meter installation is consistent with
all applicable regulations.
(Ord. 1803, passed 8-28-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73)









50.28  PURCHASE AND INSTALLATION OF WATER METERS FROM CITY.




   (A)   (1)   There is established fees for the purchase and
installation of water meters acquired from the City, such fees shall be as
set forth in Section 37.07 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the
Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.





      (2)   These fees are for the meter and the remote read-out
unit, plus labor to install the water meter in an opening plumbed by the
owner; also, the remote read-out is to be connected to wires provided and
installed by the owner.










   (B)   The fees, as established, shall be paid by the applicant to
the city at the time application is made for the meter installation; such fee
to be used by the city to defray the costs of the materials and labor
involved.










   (C)   The City Manager is authorized to increase the fees listed in
division (A) and set forth in Section 37.07 of Chapter 37, General Fee
Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton as he
deems necessary from time to time to ensure that the city receives
appropriate fees for this meter installation service.  (Ord. 2245, passed
3-10-81; amend. Ord. 3436, passed 12-22-09)









50.29  RESIDENTIAL SEPTAGE DISPOSAL SERVICE AT WASTEWATER TREATMENT PLANT.




   (A)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to implement a septage
disposal service for haulers of residential septage registered with the
County Health Department.










   (B)   The charge for this septage disposal service shall be $25 for
each 500 gallon or part thereof of septage dumped.










   (C)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to establish the
necessary procedure for implementing this septage disposal service.





(Res. 23-89, passed 8-8-89)









50.30  BOARD OF WATER AND SEWER CHARGE ADJUSTMENT.




   (A)   A Board of Water and Sewer Charge Adjustment is hereby
established, consisting of the Service Director, a citizen appointed by
Council and a council member designated by majority vote of Council.  The
citizen appointed by Council shall be appointed for a three-year term.










   (B)   The purpose of the Board of Water and Sewer Charge Adjustment
shall be to hear requests for adjustments in amounts of water and sewer
charges billed, when it is felt that the application of this chapter results
in an inequitable situation.










   (C)   An applicant may petition the Board and the Board may grant an
adjustment if the applicant proves to the Board's satisfaction that the
adjustment is justified.










   (D)   The members of the Board of Water and Sewer Charge Adjustment
may, from time to time, adopt and amend rules of procedure, to assist in
effecting the purpose of this section.  A copy of any such rules or
amendments shall be filed with the Clerk of Council prior to becoming
effective.










   (E)   Minutes of the hearings by the Board of Water and Sewer Charge
Adjustment will be kept and will also be filed with the Clerk of Council.





(Ord. 2354, passed 12-14-82)









50.99  PENALTY.




   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined as set
forth in Section 37.08 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified
Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.





(Ord. 1803, passed 10-9-73; amend. Ord. 1809, passed 10-9-73; amend. Ord.
3436, passed 12-22-09.)
























CHAPTER 51
WATER AND SEWER TAP FEES; REGULATIONS









Section










51.01   Water and sewer connection permits required





51.02   Water tap fees





51.03   Sewer tap fees





51.04   Permit required; prior to construction





51.05   Deferment of tap payment





51.06   Service installation standards





51.07   Inspection required prior to backfilling





51.08   Failure to obtain inspection; stopping work





51.09   Stop work order





51.10   Water and sewer service lines; responsibility for maintenance





51.11   Permit for construction water





51.12   Commercial and industrial sewer waste controls





51.13   Fire hydrant use





51.14   Sanitary sewer lines and septic tanks near water wells





51.15   Public/private water interconnections





51.16   Clean water prohibited from sanitary sewer





51.17   Supplementary tap fee for enlargement or charge of use





51.18   Supplementary tap fee for connection to certain water mains or
sewer mains





51.19   Backflow prevention device





51.20   Private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply





51.21   Surveys and investigations of properties served by the public
water supply





51.22   Inspection of piping system





51.23   Discontinuance of water service





51.99   Penalty




 



51.01  WATER AND SEWER CONNECTION PERMITS REQUIRED.




   No person shall connect with the city water system or sanitary sewer
system without a permit therefor. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)









51.02  WATER TAP FEES.




   (A)    The fee for a water tap into the city water system shall be
as set forth in Section 37.09 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the
Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.










   (B)    Anything not covered by the provisions in Section 37.09 of
Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of
West Carrollton shall be subject to the control and fee fixed by the
legislative body.










   (C)   The fees to be paid prior to extension of service line beyond
curb valve.










   (D)   The Water Department will make the tap into the main for the
services from 3/4 inch to and including 2 inches.










   (E)   The city will install meter in opening provided by owner or
contractor.  Cost of meter, remote and installation charges will be paid by
the owner.










   (F)   Existing taps that are reused shall be charged an inspection
fee as set forth in Section 37.09 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the
Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.





(Ord. 3354.  Passed 8-14-07; amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









51.03  SEWER TAP FEES.




   (A)    The fee for a sewer tap into the city sewer system shall be
based on meter size and such fee shall be as set forth in Section 37.10 of
Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of
West Carrollton.










   (B)    Anything not covered by the provisions in Section 37.10 of
Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of
West Carrollton shall be subject to the control and fee fixed by Council.










   (C)    Existing taps that are reused shall be charged an inspection
fee as set forth in Section 37.10 of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the
Codified Ordinances of the City of West Carrollton.





(Ord. 3355.  Passed 8-14-07; amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









51.04  PERMIT REQUIRED; PRIOR TO  CONSTRUCTION.




   Prior to the commencement of construction of water or sewer service in
any premises, a tap permit must be obtained at the office of the Water
Department. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)









51.05  DEFERMENT OF TAP PAYMENT.




   Normally, tap fees must be paid before the tap is made.  However, in
the case of new plats under construction where streets or thoroughfares have
not been paved or completed, if in the opinion of the City Manager the
completion of the services to the property line is warranted, taps will be
made, and service extended by contractor to the property line.  The tap fee
will be paid prior to the extension beyond the property line. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)









51.06  SERVICE INSTALLATION STANDARDS.




   All service installations and extensions shall be made in accordance
with the rules and regulations of the department governing plumbers, and in
conformance with the uniform building code.  Except in cases where written
permission by the Service Director is granted, each separate building will be
served through an individual meter installed in a manner acceptable to the
Service Director.





(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.07  INSPECTION REQUIRED PRIOR TO BACKFILLING.




   Any person, firm or corporation installing any water line, sanitary
sewer line or laterals in any street, or making any improvements thereto is
required to notify the respective city inspector and secure an inspection
thereof before the improvement is backfilled or in any manner covered up by
earth or other material.
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)









51.08  FAILURE TO OBTAIN INSPECTION;  STOPPING WORK.




   Any person, firm or corporation who shall backfill or in any other way
cover any water or sewer main or service line without first having obtained
an inspection thereof, as herein provided, shall, at their own expense,
re-excavate or uncover such improvement or installation in order that the 
same may be adequately inspected. Upon the refusal of any person, firm or
corporation to re-excavate or uncover, as required, no further work shall be
done on the improvement until the re-excavation or uncovering has been
completed, inspection made and approval granted. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.09  STOP WORK ORDER.




   City inspectors are hereby authorized to stop any work, construction or
installation of any water or sanitary sewer improvements in the event of
violation of or deviation from the specifications governing the work,
construction, installation or improvement.





(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)









51.10  WATER AND SEWER SERVICE LINES; RESPONSIBILITY FOR MAINTENANCE.




   (A)   Water and sewer service lines are installed by the property
owner at his expense.  The property owner shall be responsible for any water
leakage which may occur between the curb valve and the point of consumption,
and shall be responsible for any blockage or leakage which may occur in the
sanitary sewer service lines.










   (B)   Repairs to service lines shall conform to all specifications,
procedures and inspections applicable to  installation  of  new  service
lines. However,  if repair or reconstruction of a service line does not
require a relocated or enlarged tap, the tap fee shall not apply. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.11  PERMIT FOR CONSTRUCTION WATER.




   (A)   Any person, firm, or corporation constructing a building or
buildings for which a water tap into the municipal system is required shall
secure from the city a permit for construction water, the fee for which shall
be based upon the total estimated construction cost of the building or
buildings according to the schedule set forth in Section 37.11 of Chapter 37,
General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City of West
Carrollton.










   This permit shall be obtained and paid for at the time the building
permit is secured.  This provision shall not apply to the construction of
garages, storage sheds, or additions to existing buildings, where water under
meter control is already being billed.










   (B)   The use of construction water includes the right to use water
for construction purposes, sanitation purposes, and for the testing of water
and sewer lines during the construction phase, but in no event shall the
right to use the water extend beyond the time of the final inspection, or the
cessation of normal building activities when the construction is complete or
purposely held incomplete, whichever is earliest.  (Ord. 1805, passed
9-25-73; amend. Ord. 2209, passed 6-10-80; amend. Ord. 2349, passed
10-12-82)  Penalty, see § 51.99










   (C)   Any person, firm, or corporation requesting temporary water
usage for an existing building construction or maintenance project shall
submit a refundable fire hydrant meter deposit as set forth in Section 37.11
of Chapter 37, General Fee Schedule, of the Codified Ordinances of the City
of West Carrollton.  Water usage shall be the current minimum charge in
effect for a 5/8" - 3/4" meter, plus the current additional charge per 1,000
gallons used over the minimum 10,000 gallons. 





(Ord. 3349.  Passed 8-14-07; amend. Ord. 3436.  Passed 12-22-09.)









51.12  COMMERCIAL AND INDUSTRIAL SEWER WASTE CONTROLS.




   (A)   For businesses using oils, gasolines, greases, fats and other
problem substances, sumps which prevent entry of these products into
sanitary  sewer shall be required, and such sumps must be regularly
maintained to prevent accumulation and overflow of sludge and other
non-degradable products into the sanitary sewer.










   (B)   The city reserves the right to monitor wastes and to refuse to
accept those wastes which cannot be fully digested in the normal operation of
the wastewater treatment plant, or which adversely affect the operation of
the sewer system.  When approved by the city, industrial wastes must be
pretreated, then analyzed and charges assessed based on cost of additional
treatment provided by the city.










   (C)   Disposal of any toxic materials through the city sewer system
is expressly prohibited. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73; amend. Ord. 2134, passed 6-12-79)  Penalty, see
§ 51.99









51.13  FIRE HYDRANT USE.




   No person shall open or use water from any fire hydrant without first
obtaining a permit therefor, and no person shall open or close a fire hydrant
except with a hydrant wrench provided by the city.
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.14  SANITARY SEWER LINES AND SEPTIC TANKS NEAR WATER WELLS.




   No person shall construct or maintain any sanitary sewer line within
500 feet of any well used in connection with or constituting a part of the
water works system of the city, unless the construction of such line is
approved by the city and the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) in
writing.  Septic tanks and/or leaching fields may not be constructed or
maintained within 500 feet of any such well. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.15  PUBLIC PRIVATE WATER  INTERCONNECTIONS.




   No consumer shall have a cross connection between his private water
supply and the city water system unless such cross connection has been
approved by the Ohio EPA and the Service Director. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.16  CLEAN WATER PROHIBITED FROM  SANITARY SEWER.




   No person shall construct or maintain connections into the sanitary
sewer from roof drains, foundation drains or other sources of clean water
which should be carried away by storm sewers or drains.
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.17  SUPPLEMENTARY TAP FEE FOR  ENLARGEMENT OR CHANGE OF USE.




   In the event that a structure is enlarged, or the use of a structure is
materially changed, the owner or occupant may be required to pay a
supplementary tap fee prior to the issuance of a building and/ or occupancy
permit.  A supplementary tap fee shall be charged if the tap fee for the
original use or structure, computed according to the current schedule of tap
fees, is less than the tap fee for the newly established use or enlarged
structure, computed according to the current schedule of tap fees.  The
supplementary tap fee to be charged shall be the difference between these 2
computations. 
(Ord. 1812, passed 11-13-73)









51.18  SUPPLEMENTARY TAP FEE FOR  CONNECTION TO CERTAIN WATER MAINS OR
SEWER MAINS.




   (A)   Should any sewer main or water main be installed by a private
party and run along a course which makes the water or sewer main available to
lands other than those of the installer of the water main or sewer main, the
city shall enter into an agreement with the installer whereby the city agrees
to prohibit any other properties from being connected thereto unless the
owner thereof has:





      (1)   Obtained a permit for such a connection from the Service
Director of the city.





      (2)   Paid to the city a supplementary tap fee (or
“protection”) in addition to the tap fees described in §§ 51.02 and
51.03.  The amount of protection established shall be based upon a
percentage of the front footage of the properties benefited by the water or
sewer main.  The city shall reimburse the amount of this supplementary tap
fee to the owner of the property for which the water or sewer main was
originally installed.










   (B)   A preliminary request for protection shall be submitted by the
installer with the cost estimate for the proposed improvement prior to
approval by the Service Director.










   (C)   A property owner installing water or sewer mains and
requesting protection shall be required to extend the water or sewer
improvements across the entire front of his property in cases where there is
additional property beyond the owner's property which can be served by water
or sewer service.










   (D)   A letter requesting protection shall be submitted to the
Service Director within 30 days after final city approval of the water or
sewer main improvement.  The Service Director shall verify the cost of
installation of the water or sewer mains before approving the protection
agreement.










   (E)   This protection agreement shall be in effect for 20 years
after the date of approval.










   (F)   The city accepts no liability for collection of protection
monies due to error or oversight by the city. 
(Ord. 2551, passed 5-27-86)  Penalty, see § 51.99









51.19  BACKFLOW PREVENTION DEVICE.




   If, in the judgment of the Service Director, an approved backflow
prevention device is necessary for the safety of the public water system, the
Director will give notice to the water consumer to install such an approved
device.  The water consumer, at his own expense, shall install such an
approved device at a location and in a manner approved by the Director and
shall have inspections and tests made of such approved devices as required by
the Director.





(Ord. 2581, passed 3-10-87)









51.20  PRIVATE, AUXILIARY, OR EMERGENCY  WATER SUPPLY.




   No person, firm, or corporation shall establish or permit to be
established or maintain or permit to be maintained any connection whereby a
private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply other than the regular public
water supply of the city may enter the supply or distributing system of the
city, unless such private, auxiliary, or emergency water supply and the
method of connection and use  of  such supply  shall have been approved by
the Director and by the Ohio Environmental Protection Agency.





(Ord. 2581, passed 3-10-87)









51.21  SURVEYS AND INVESTIGATIONS OF  PROPERTIES SERVED BY THE PUBLIC
WATER  SUPPLY.




   It shall be the duty of the Service Director to cause surveys and
investigations to be made of industrial and other properties served by the
public water supply where actual or potential hazards to the public water
supply may exist.  The surveys and investigations shall be repeated as often
as the Director shall deem necessary.





(Ord. 2581, passed 3-10-87)









51.22  INSPECTION OF PIPING SYSTEM.




   The Service Director or his duly authorized representative shall have
the right to enter at any reasonable time any property served by a connection
to the public water supply or distributing system of the city for the purpose
of inspecting the piping system or systems thereof.  On the demand the
owner, lessees, or occupants of any property so serviced shall furnish to the
Director any information which he may request regarding the piping system or
systems or water use on such property.  The refusal of such information,
when demanded, shall, within the discretion of the Director, be deemed
evidence of the presence of improper connections as provided in §§ 51.19
through 51.23.





(Ord. 2581, passed 3-10-87)









51.23  DISCONTINUANCE OF WATER SERVICE.




   The Service Director is hereby authorized and directed to discontinue,
after reasonable notice to the occupant thereof, the water service to any
property wherein any connection in violation of the provisions of §§ 51.19
through 51.23 is known to exist, and to take such other precautionary
measures as he may deem necessary to eliminate any danger of contamination of
the public water supply distribution mains.  Water service to the property
shall not be restored until the conditions shall have been eliminated or
corrected in compliance with the provisions of §§ 51.19 through 51.23.





(Ord. 2581, passed 3-10-87)









51.99  PENALTY.




   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be guilty of a
misdemeanor of the first degree and shall be fined not more than $1,000 or
imprisoned for not more than 6 months, or both. 
(Ord. 1805, passed 9-25-73; amend. Ord. 2140, passed 6-26-79)
























CHAPTER 52
WATER AND SEWER SERVICE LINES









Section










52.01   Stop work order





52.02   Inspection required prior to backfilling





52.03   Failure to obtain inspection; stopping work





52.04   Drains near water wells





52.99   Penalty




 



52.01  STOP WORK ORDER.




   City inspectors are hereby authorized to stop any work, construction or
installation of any water, sanitary sewer and storm sewer lines and
improvements thereto in the event the same is found to be in violation of or
in deviation from the specifications governing the work, construction,
installation or improvement. 
('70 Code, § 915.01)









52.02  INSPECTION REQUIRED PRIOR TO  BACKFILLING.




   Any person, firm or corporation installing any water line, storm sewer
line, sanitary sewer line or laterals or any street, or making any
improvements thereto, is required to notify the respective city inspector and
secure an inspection thereof before the improvement is backfilled or in any
manner covered up by earth or other substance.
('70 Code, § 915.02)  Penalty, see § 52.99









52.03  FAILURE TO OBTAIN INSPECTION;  STOPPING WORK.




   Any person, firm or corporation who shall backfill or in any other way
cover any improvement without first having obtained an inspection thereof, as
herein provided, shall, at their own expense, re-excavate or uncover such
improvement or installation in order that the same way be adequately
inspected.  Upon refusal of any person, firm or corporation to so
re-excavate or uncover, as required, no further work shall be done on the
improvement until the re-excavation or uncovering has been completed,
inspection made and approval thereof secured. 
('70 Code, § 915.03)  Penalty, see § 52.99









52.04  DRAINS NEAR WATER WELLS.




   No person shall construct or maintain any drain within 500 feet of
any  well used in connection with or constituting a part of the water works
system of the city. 
('70 Code, § 915.04)  Penalty, see § 52.99









52.99  PENALTY.




   Whoever violates any provision of this chapter shall be fined not more
than $50.  Each day's continued violation shall constitute a separate
offense. 
('70 Code, § 915.99)
























CHAPTER 53
GARBAGE AND TRASH REMOVAL









Section










53.01   Definitions





53.02   Container requirements





53.03   Contents of containers





53.04   Supervision of waste collection and removal





53.05   Placement of containers for collection





53.06   Special collections





53.07   Dumpster and other private hauler containers





53.08   Burying or burning garbage prohibited





53.09   On-call refuse collection service





53.10   Grass and lawn debris collection and disposal





53.11   Exclusive rights to collect





53.12   Waste disposal fee





53.13   Delinquency; collection





53.99   Penalty




 



53.01  DEFINITIONS.




   For the purpose of this chapter the following words and phrases shall
have the following meanings ascribed to them respectively.





   (A)   GARBAGE.  Putrescible wastes, and includes every refuse
accumulation of animal, fruit or vegetable matter, used or intended for food,
or that attends the preparation, use, cooking, dealing in or storing of meat,
fish, fowl, fruit or vegetables.










   (B)   TRASH.  All waste capable of being burned, such as wooden or
cardboard boxes, crates and cartons, wooden barrels, lumber scraps or
shavings, rags or discarded wearing apparel and bedding, excelsior, straw,
grass, leaves, lawn, flower,  shrubbery or tree trimmings, paper and
magazines or any other material capable of being burned.  The term TRASH
also includes ashes, glass, tin cans, crockery, metal, junk or other
nonburnable waste.










   (C)   WASTE.  All trash, rubbish, garbage and other refuse or
discarded material required to be removed from private and public places,
exclusive of recognized industrial by-products; or any highly explosive
materials;  or  any  poisonous  substance whatsoever.  For the purpose
of this chapter, the materials shall be classified as garbage and trash. 










   (D)   GRASS. Plant life waste which accumulates through the yard
mowing process.










   (E)   LAWN DEBRIS.  Plant life waste which includes leaves, thatch,
light brush, shrubbery trimmings, weeds and crop residue.










   (F)   PRIVATE WASTE COLLECTOR.  “Private waste collector” shall
mean any person, firm or corporation engaged in the practice of operating
their own trucks for the removal of their own waste, and not in the
commercial waste collection business.





(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.02  CONTAINER REQUIREMENTS.



   The City shall collect and dispose of waste from containers provided or
approved, by the City.  It shall be the duty of every resident, retailer,
wholesaler, dealer in food stuff, and every person, firm, or corporation to
provide or cause to be provided a portable container or containers for
storage of waste materials approved by the City.



 



   (A)   Mobile Containers (Toters).  These containers shall be
provided by or acquired from the city.  The City will provide one toter per
customer.  Expected lifespan of this toter is typically 10-12 years. 
Replacement of this toter due to damage or neglect by the customer will be
the responsibility of the customer.  Additional toters, shall be purchased
from the city at the current cost shown in the General Fee Schedule. 
Effective the first quarter of 2016, the cost per toter is $81.00.



 



   (B)   Residential garbage containers.  These containers shall be
galvanized iron, plastic, or other nonrusting material of substantial
construction.  They shall hold not less than 10, nor more than 32 gallons;
but in no case will the combined weight of the container and contents exceed
50 pounds.  Containers shall have handles on the outside by which they may
be lifted and emptied; they shall be water-tight and provided with
tight-fitting lids to keep out water and animals.  The lids shall be
equipped with a handle and shall be kept in place except when removed to
empty or load the container.  Plastic refuse can liners, not to exceed 32
gallons capacity or 50 pounds in weight, may be used if littering and animals
are not a problem.



 




   (C)   Trash containers.  Trash containers may be baskets, crates or
containers of such size (50 pounds maximum) as may be easily handled by one
man and substantial enough not to be broken in handling.  Cardboard cartons
should not be used when there is danger of precipitation.  Wet cardboard
containers will be refused. Containers will be maintained in a sanitary
condition at all times. These containers are to be covered to prevent
littering at all times.  (Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.03 CONTENTS OF CONTAINERS.



   Each resident using the municipal refuse collection system shall place
or cause to be placed in containers as hereinbefore described, all waste
created or accumulated on his premises or the premises under his control; and
no person or persons shall throw, place, or deposit any waste materials on
any public or private property.  All garbage shall be drained of excess
liquids or fluids and wrapped in paper before depositing in containers, in
order that the material may be easily removed.  All grass shall be handled
as described in §53.10.  Shrubbery or tree trimmings are not required to be
placed in containers but must first be cut into lengths of not more than four
feet and tied into bundles not more than 18 inches in diameter, before the
material will be removed by the municipal trash collection service.  No
person shall place in any container any industrial or commercial waste, any
explosive, or any poisonous substance whatsoever.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.04  SUPERVISION OF WASTE COLLECTION AND REMOVAL.



   It shall be the duty of the Service Director to supervise the
collection and removal of residential waste within the city.  That subject
to the approval of the City Manager, the Service Director shall establish and
update when necessary the refuse policies governing the city waste collection
services.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.05  PLACEMENT OF CONTAINERS FOR  COLLECTION.




   Containers of waste material shall be placed in a readily accessible
location at curb side or in alley at each premise before 6:00 a.m. on  the 
day  scheduled for pickup.  Due to littering problems, in no case shall the
material be placed at curb side earlier than 5:00 p.m. of the day preceding
the scheduled collection day.  All containers shall be removed from the
collection area by 4:30 p.m. of the day following collection day.  Other
than described herein, no containers shall be kept in the area in front of
the house or garage.  In no event will refuse be removed by city crews from
garages, buildings, or any location other than dedicated and improved city
streets or alleys.  It shall be the responsibility of the owner or his agent
to clean up in the refuse collection area any materials spilled by reason
of  improper  containers,  overloading of containers, or littering by
animals, or severe weather.  (Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28- 16.)









53.06  SPECIAL COLLECTIONS.




   The City may provide additional waste collection and disposal services
as needed.  Collection of materials that will not fit in a standard
container or that pose special collection difficulties will be made once
quarterly during the months of January, May, July, and October.  At that
time materials such as appliances, furniture, tree and shrubbery trimmings,
automotive and other metal parts, and materials from home alterations (when
work performed by the home owner or occupant) will be collected.  These
materials will be collected from the same location at curbside or alley as
the regular refuse pickup.  When weather conditions, labor or mechanical
problems occur, the City reserves the right to cancel or reschedule these
collections.  If any mattress, furniture, or other item is found to contain
Bed Bugs, those items will be tagged with a hanger and will not be picked
up.  Those items containing Bed Bugs shall be removed from the collection
area by the customer, wrapped in plastic, and sealed with tape and then
placed out for the next available pick up.  (Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.07  DUMPSTER AND OTHER PRIVATE HAULER CONTAINERS.




   It shall be the responsibility of the owner or occupant to maintain
these in a sanitary and nuisance-free condition.  They shall be rodent-proof
and emptied at such intervals as to prevent fly and litter problems.  The
areas around these containers shall be kept free of litter and rodents at all
times.  (Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.08  BURYING OR BURNING GARBAGE  PROHIBITED.




   No person shall bury or burn any garbage, as defined in § 53.01, or
throw or leave the same in or upon any street, court, lane, alley, public
square, public enclosure, vacant lot or in any pond, stream or body of water
or branch thereof within the limits of the city. However, on the days
scheduled by council for the collection of the waste, the vessel, vessels or
containers containing the same may be placed on the premises in obedience to
and in compliance with § 53.05.  (Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.09  ON-CALL REFUSE COLLECTION SERVICE.



   (A)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to continue the on-call
special refuse collection service to those properties normally served by the
weekly and quarterly refuse collection service.



 



   (B)   The current cost for on-call refuse collection is as shown in
the General Fee Schedule.  Effective the first quarter of 2016, the on-call
refuse collection cost is $21.00 per occurrence.  The charge for this
service shall be for items that can be handled by a maximum of two employees
without the need of motorized equipment.  Should a pickup require motorized
equipment to assist in lifting, or be extensive enough to exceed one-half
hour in duration, additional fees will be assessed at the current rates for
dumping, manpower and equipment necessary to accomplish the pickup.  In such
case, an estimate of probable additional costs will be given to the property
owner prior to the pickup.



 



   (C)   During the quarterly pick up periods in January, May, July and
October, pickups requiring motorized equipment to assist in lifting, or to be
extended enough to exceed one-half hour in duration, will also have
additional fees assessed at the current rates for dumping, manpower and
equipment necessary to accomplish the pickup.  In such case, an estimate of
probable additional costs will be given to the property owner prior to the
pickup.



 



   (D)   Items as described in §53.06 and subject to special
collection service that are placed for collection but unscheduled shall have
the customer notified by hanger or letter or certified mail or personal
contact to remedy the pickup themselves or remove said items from the
collection area within 48 hours.  After 48 hours, the city will enact the
special collection and assess a fee for this service.  The current cost of
this unscheduled collection is as shown in the General Fee Schedule. 
Effective the date of passing this Ordinance, the unscheduled collection fee
is $21.00 (on call collection service) plus $28.00 (administrative fee) for a
total of $49.00.  Fee for this service shall be for items that can be
handled by a maximum of two employees without the need of motorized
equipment.  Should a pickup require motorized equipment to assist in
lifting, or be extensive enough to exceed one-half hour in duration,
additional fees will be assessed at the current rates for dumping, manpower
and equipment necessary to accomplish the pickup.  In such case, an estimate
of probable additional costs will be given to the property owner prior to the
pickup.



 



   (E)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to establish the
necessary procedures for this special refuse collection service.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.10  GRASS AND LAWN DEBRIS COLLECTION AND DISPOSAL.



   (A)   It shall be the responsibility of each resident to separate
grass from other trash bagged and set out for collection by city refuse crews
and this grass shall be contained in special bags identified for the purpose
of yard waste disposal in the city.  Brush tied in bundles, bagged lawn
debris other than grass,  and leaves raked to the curb for the annual fall
collection can be set out with regular refuse for collection.



 



   (B)   The special bags to be used for the purpose of grass disposal
shall be available from the city and may be made available at those retail
outlets within the city that wish to offer the bags for sale.  The current
cost for special bags is as shown in the General Fee Schedule.  Effective
for the first quarter of 2016, the cost is $1.35 per bag.



 



   (C)   The City Manager is hereby authorized to establish the
necessary procedure for implementing this program for the collection and
disposal of grass.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.11  EXCLUSIVE RIGHTS TO COLLECT.



   To provide for residential garbage, refuse and/or recyclable
collection, and to control truck traffic in its residential areas, the City
shall hold exclusive rights to collect and dispose of garbage and refuse from
residential households.  No other person  or agency shall be permitted to
collect such material for hire in the City.  Private waste collectors are
permitted to collect refuse for residential apartments, and commercial and
industrial establishments not serviced by the City.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.12  WASTE DISPOSAL FEE.



   The City may charge the owner, or assess the property, or both, for the
cost of collecting and disposing of waste from property located within the
City.  The current cost for refuse collection is as shown in the General Fee
Schedule.  Effective with the first quarter of 2016, the fee for refuse
collection service shall be $51.09 per quarter.



 



   The fee is for the weekly collection and disposal of waste by the City
from a waste container provided by the City, or a like quantity of waste in a
container approved by the City.  Each residence and business serviced by the
City shall have its own waste container or containers.  For purposes of this
section, a residence is each unit in an apartment or housing complex and each
part of a house or residential structure providing separate living quarters,
including a bath, kitchen, and sleeping room, for an individual or group of
individuals, related or otherwise.  For purposes of this section, a business
is each unit in a commercial building or strip center for an individual or
group of individuals.  The fee is also for the quarterly pickup of large
items as set forth in Section 53.06, leaf collection, and also for the
recyclables collection service.



 



   The City shall include the fee on the property owner’s utility bill,
or as a separate bill, and the property owner shall pay the fee in the manner
and amount specified on the bill.  A property owner may, by agreement,
require a tenant or lawful occupant of the property to pay to the City the
fee; however, in the event of nonpayment, the property owner remains
responsible for paying the fee.




(Ord. 3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)









53.13  DELINQUENCY; COLLECTION.




   All fees for refuse collection are due and payable upon receipt.  If
the bill is not paid on or before the fifteenth day after mailing such
notice, a penalty of ten percent (10%) shall be posted to the account.  If
the account is not paid within 28 days after mailing such notice, a 48-hour
notice of service shut-off shall be mailed to the affected address and to the
owner if that address is not his place of residence.  If more than one user
is to be affected by such shut-off, notices shall be mailed to all persons. 
If the bill is not paid upon the expiration of the 48-hour period, the
Finance Director may certify such charges to the County Auditor, who shall
place the same on the tax duplicate and collect the charges thereon and
penalties therefor in the same manner as other taxes are collected.  (Ord.
3587.  Passed 6-28- 16.)









53.99  PENALTY.




   Any person, firm or corporation doing anything declared by this chapter
to be unlawful or failing or refusing to perform any duty set forth in this
chapter shall be fined not more than $50 for each day of violation.  (Ord.
3587.  Passed 6-28-16.)
























CHAPTER 54
PREVAILING WAGE LAW









Section










54.01   Wages and hours on public works




 



54.01  WAGES AND HOURS ON PUBLIC WORKS.




   (A)   R.C. §§ 4115.01 through 4115.16, as amended from time to
time, sometimes referred to as the prevailing wage laws, are hereby expressly
declared not to be incorporated into the ordinances of the city.










   (B)   Neither the city council nor any city officers or employees
shall be bound by any of the provisions of the state statutes known as the
prevailing wage laws, nor shall they designate a prevailing wage coordinator
to perform any responsibilities set forth in those statutes.










   (C)   Contracts entered into by the city shall not comply with the
prevailing wage statutes except to the extent any subsequent legislation
specifically provides to the contrary or except to the extent the city is
required to comply with the statutes as a condition of obtaining funds. 
(Ord. 2233, passed 12-23-80)
























CHAPTER 55
HAZARDOUS MATERIALS









Section










55.01   Definitions





55.02   Discharge of hazardous materials; cleanup or abatement; liability
for costs





55.03   Billing responsible persons; payment to the city; appeal




 



Off-Site Infectious Waste Treatment Facility or Treatment Facility



 




55.15   Fee





55.16   Definitions





55.17   Return; remittance of fee





55.18   Disposition of fee





55.99   Penalty




 



55.01  DEFINITIONS.




   For the purpose of this chapter, the following definitions shall apply
unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.










   COST INCURRED BY CITY.  Includes all costs and expenses of the city in
connection with the cleanup or abatement of the discharge of hazardous
materials or the extinguishing of a fire involving hazardous materials and
shall include, but shall not necessarily be limited to the following: actual
labor costs of city personnel involved in cleanup or abatement of the
discharge (including workers compensation benefits, fringe benefit and
administrative overhead); cost of equipment operation, damage or loss as
published and updated by the Finance Department of the city; cost of
materials obtained by the city; and cost of any contract labor and materials.










   DISCHARGE.  To leak, seep, spill or otherwise release.










   HAZARDOUS MATERIAL.  Any substance or material which, due to its
quantity, form, concentration, location, or other characteristics, is
determined by the Fire Chief or his authorized representatives, to pose an
unreasonable and imminent risk to life, health or safety of persons or
property or to the ecological balance of the environment including, but not
limited to, explosives, radioactive materials, petroleum or petroleum
products or gases, poisons, etiologic (biological) agents, flammables,
corrosives, or any substance determined  to  be  hazardous  or  toxic 
under  any federal or state law, statute or regulations.










   THIRD PARTY.  Any person, company or business entity other than the
city and its officers and employees.





(Ord. 2802, passed 5-28-91)









55.02  DISCHARGE OF HAZARDOUS MATERIALS; CLEANUP OR ABATEMENT; LIABILITY FOR
COSTS.




   (A)   It shall be unlawful to discharge any hazardous materials in
the city without first obtaining a permit from all appropriate federal and
state authorities as well as the Fire Chief.










   (B)   The Fire Department is authorized to clean up, or abate the
effects of, any hazardous material discharged upon or into any property or
facilities within the city where such discharge creates a hazard to
individuals, property or the environment.  The Fire Department may be
assisted in such cleanup or abatement by any other fire department or any
third parties as necessary to protect against or eliminate such hazard.










   (C)   Any person who discharges, or otherwise causes a discharge of,
hazardous material and any person who owns or controls the hazardous
materials container at the time of discharge shall be jointly and severally
liable to the city for the payment of all costs incurred by the city as a
result of such cleanup or abatement by the city, regardless of fault.










   (D)   For purposes of this chapter, the person who discharges or
causes the discharge of hazardous materials, or who owns or controls the
container at the time of discharge, if an individual, shall include that
individual's employer and any related entity of the employer; if a
corporation or partnership, that person shall include any entity legally
related to such corporation or partnership.










   (E)   The authority to recover costs incurred by the city shall not
include costs for fire suppressing services which are normally or customarily
provided by the Fire Department unless the fire involves hazardous materials
or services not normally or customarily provided by the Fire Department.










   (F)   The remedies provided by this chapter shall be in addition to
any other remedies provided by law.





(Ord. 2802, passed 5-28-91)









55.03  BILLING RESPONSIBLE PERSONS; PAYMENT TO THE CITY; APPEAL.




   (A)   The city shall within 60 days of completion of the cleanup or
abatement of any hazardous material discharge, send an invoice for the costs
incurred by the city in connection with such discharge to the person
determined by the city to be responsible for such discharge pursuant to this
chapter.










   (B)   The person responsible for such hazardous material discharge
shall submit payment for the invoice to the city within 30 days of receipt of
the invoice.










   (C)   Any person determined by the city to be responsible for a
hazardous material discharge may appeal to the City Manager any invoice sent
pursuant to this section by sending a written notice of appeal to the City
Manager within 15 days of receipt of the invoice.  The appeal shall be heard
by the City Manager and his decision shall be final.










   (D)   The city may institute an action for the recovery of costs
billed, or take any other action provided by law.





(Ord. 2802, passed 5-28-91)










OFF-SITE INFECTIOUS WASTE





TREATMENT FACILITY OR TREATMENT FACILITY









55.15  FEE.




   A fee of $5 per ton is levied upon all off-site infectious waste
treatment facilities and/or treatment facilities located within the city, for
the treatment of infectious waste at the treatment facility.





(Res. 34-93, passed  -  -)









55.16  DEFINITIONS.




   For the purpose of this subchapter, the following definitions shall
apply unless the context clearly indicates or requires a different meaning.










   INFECTIOUS WASTE.  Has the same meaning as provided in R.C. § 3734.01.










   OFF-SITE INFECTIOUS WASTE TREATMENT FACILITY and TREATMENT FACILITY. 
Have the same meaning as provided in R.C. § 3734.023.





(Res. 34-93, passed  -  -)









55.17  RETURN; REMITTANCE OF FEE.




   (A)   The owner or operator of an off-site infectious waste
treatment facility shall pay the fees levied herein monthly to the City
Finance Director in accordance with rules adopted by the Ohio Director of
Environmental Protection under R.C. § 3734.026.  The remittance of such fee
shall be accompanied by a return indicating the total amount of infectious
waste received at the facility for treatment during the month to which the
return applies.










   (B)   If the monthly return and remittance of the fees are not
submitted to the Finance Director within 60 days after the last day of the
month to which the return and the remittance apply or within 60 days after
the date otherwise established by the Ohio Director of Environmental
Protection, the owner or operation shall pay a penalty of an additional 50%
of the amount of the remittance for each month it is late.





(Res. 34-93, passed  -  -)









55.18  DISPOSITION OF FEE.




   The money received by the Finance Director shall be paid into the
general fund of the city for the purpose of providing funding or conducting
environmental monitoring programs in connection with the off-site infectious
waste treatment facilities located within the city; providing local emergency
response services in connection with such a facility and transportation of
infectious waste to such a facility; and providing financial assistance to
the Montgomery County Board of Health for the enforcement of the infectious
waste provisions of the Ohio Revised Code and rules, orders, terms and
conditions of permits and licenses adopted or issued under such provisions.





(Res. 34-93, passed  -  -)









55.99  PENALTY.




   Whoever violates § 55.17 shall be fined not more than $10,000.  Each
day the violation continues shall constitute a separate offense.





(Res. 34-93, passed  -  -)
